Indeed, in the initial years of Erdoğan’s tenure as prime minister, he was widely lauded internationally for his democratic leadership and liberal reforms—a marked contrast with the criticism the Trump administration attracted for its early disregard for democratic norms.<sup class="footnote">80</sup> Although this initial period did feature some encroachment on democratic institutions, Erdoğan’s erosion of Türkiye’s democratic institutions did not accelerate significantly until years later.<sup class="footnote">81</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>India, too, exemplifies the gradualness that usually characterizes the common democratic backsliding model. Modi did not immediately dismantle democratic institutions at the outset of his tenure as prime minister in 2014. Rather, over the subsequent decade he has utilized his strong parliamentary backing and repressive techniques step by step to centralize power and create a culture of fear that prevents meaningful civil society mobilization or political opposition. His government only incrementally employed tools such as sedition laws, retribution against political opponents, and restrictions on media and civil society. These tactics are comparable to the United States, where Trump’s early assault on U.S. law firms through targeted executive orders quickly led other law firms to acquiesce to the administration’s demands. But while this unfolded over mere weeks in the United States, it was the accumulative use of such measures over years in India that has suppressed meaningful pushback by civil society and judicial bodies.<sup class="footnote">82</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Not all cases of backsliding unfold slowly. In some cases, leaders with backsliding intent enact an immediate, rapid agenda to overcome a position of political weakness. In Ecuador, for example, while Correa won the 2007 presidential election, he faced strong opposition in the legislature that posed a meaningful constraint on his political capacity. He quickly called for a constituent assembly, which he filled with political allies. With Correa’s backing, the constituent assembly suspended Congress and vested itself with the country’s policymaking powers, co-opting the legislature completely.<sup class="footnote">83</sup> But after Correa’s initial assault on the legislature, his subsequent overreach strategy did not sustain this initial momentum. His approach over the ensuing decade was certainly aggressive, but it proceeded more slowly and incrementally. By contrast, Trump faces no major legislative pushback to his agenda that would necessitate an early power grab of this type. He is operating from a position of power and seeking to amass even more power.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>There are a few cases of executive-led democratic backsliding that more closely resemble the rapid approach of the Trump administration’s first few months. Poland’s democratic erosion, for example, was also characterized by a quick assault on democratic checks on the executive right out of the gate. PiS assumed power in October 2015 with a slim parliamentary majority. Almost immediately, the newly formed government moved to weaken the judiciary, media, and civil service. Within its first year, PiS undermined the Constitutional Tribunal by politicizing its appointments and limiting its oversight capacities, and—much like the Trump administration’s ongoing disobedience of judicial mandates—began rejecting tribunal rulings outright.<sup class="footnote">84</sup> It expanded government control over Poland’s public media services and used this power to purge critical journalists. And it politicized the country’s civil service through changes to the Civil Service Act—another move that parallels the Trump administration’s ongoing politicization of the federal bureaucracy.<sup class="footnote">85</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Hungary, too, saw a rapid expansion of executive power after Orbán and the Fidesz party regained power in May 2010. By the end of that year, the Fidesz government had packed key institutions and agencies with party loyalists, passed constitutional changes to weaken the oversight capacity of Hungary’s Constitutional Court, reduced the size of the legislature, eliminated funding for civil society groups, and passed new media restrictions.<sup class="footnote">86</sup> Much like the Trump administration, Orbán’s team asserted dominance over various levels of Hungary’s democratic system—from the co-opting of independent agencies to the weakening of civil society organizations. And, also like the Trump team’s approach, the Fidesz government enacted these changes with rapidity after assuming power.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><blockquote>Even in comparison to similar cases like Poland and Hungary, Trump’s actions over the past months reflect an unusually condensed timeline and rapid upending of democratic norms.</blockquote></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>But even in comparison to similar cases like Poland and Hungary, Trump’s actions over the past months reflect an unusually condensed timeline and rapid upending of democratic norms. While the PiS and Fidesz governments each oversaw significant democratic erosion in their first year, the Trump administration compressed into its first weeks of overt defiance and institutional disruption of democratic systems what took months to unfold in these other cases. For example, steps comparable to the series of measures that Trump took in his early days to consolidate control over the executive workforce took form over a year-long period in Hungary.<sup class="footnote">87</sup> Trump’s team began to defy the judicial system in the first weeks of his presidency. In Poland, by contrast, while the PiS government moved swiftly to reshape the Polish judiciary, it was not until months into its tenure that the party began to explicitly deny the legitimacy of the courts.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h4>Simultaneous, Multilevel Approach</h4></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>In addition to the speed of the administration’s efforts, it is also notable that it has maintained this rapid approach simultaneously across the different domains of U.S. democracy. In other backsliding cases, leaders commonly targeted their country’s democratic checks in a piece-by-piece fashion. In Türkiye, it was through incremental changes over many years that Erdoğan weakened Turkish democratic institutions in changes like the 2010 constitutional referendum to increase the executive’s control over the courts and another referendum in 2017 to weaken the legislature and establish a system with an extremely powerful presidency.<sup class="footnote">88</sup> Correa’s approach was also less unified. Over a decade, he periodically targeted democratic institutions. He first created a new executive-aggrandizing constitution. Subsequently, his government pushed through constitutional changes that weakened the judiciary and the press. It was only later that Correa implemented stringent restrictions on civil society organizations and gatherings.<sup class="footnote">89</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The Trump team has not employed this sort of institution-by-institution approach. Rather, it has aggressively pursued all three levels of its aggrandizement agenda simultaneously. During his first week as president in January 2025, Trump issued a host of executive orders, statements, and restructurings that targeted the executive branch, horizontal institutions, and civil society. And in subsequent months, the three-level effort has not let up. His team has continued to exert dominance by stacking the different elements of his aggrandizement agenda into a compressed and simultaneous push that makes identifying and responding to its illiberal elements especially challenging for pro-democracy actors.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h3>Severity: Some Limits—For Now</h3></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>While the Trump administration’s pursuit of executive dominance has been particularly fast, the degree of democratic erosion in the United States is not yet as severe as that of most of its backsliding peers. Most of America’s democratic institutions and processes remain intact, protected by the Constitution and other U.S. laws. The administration’s policies and procedures have undermined democratic norms, but its aggrandizement agenda is not, at least yet, as deeply institutionalized as in the majority of the comparative cases studied. And U.S. democracy has not devolved to the levels of political violence and repression that characterize some of the backsliding countries in this study and beyond. Yet while the United States might not have slid as far toward autocracy as many democracies before it, the weakening of what were previously viewed as unusually strong democratic guardrails is nevertheless unprecedented in modern U.S. history and deeply troubling.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h4>Non-institutionalized Backsliding</h4></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Democratic erosion has thus far been less institutionalized in the United States than in most of the comparative backsliding cases. For example, to weaken horizontal checks on the executive, Trump’s primary tactic has been the erosion of democratic norms—that is, the informal, unwritten rules of democracy—rather than structural, legal change. As discussed above, the administration has prioritized efforts to delegitimize the judiciary. This approach could ultimately pave the path for the structural weakening of the judiciary, as the Turkish case exemplifies. And the Supreme Court’s ruling in June limiting the ability of federal courts to issue universal injunctions is for some observers a worrying development in this direction.<sup class="footnote">90</sup> But the U.S. case still does not entail the types of structural judicial changes that eliminated Polish judicial independence or weakened the authority of Ecuador’s courts.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><blockquote>To weaken horizontal checks on the executive, Trump’s primary tactic has been the erosion of democratic norms—that is, the informal, unwritten rules of democracy—rather than structural, legal change.</blockquote></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Brazilian judicial delegitimization under Bolsonaro is a more similar case of normative rather than institutional democratic decline with regard to the judiciary. As outlined above, Bolsonaro leaned heavily into verbal assaults on Brazilian courts and never translated this into structural changes to Brazil’s judiciary. Throughout his tenure, the judicial system remained an independent and important democratic check on his illiberal agenda. Trump’s attacks on U.S. courts have already gone further than Bolsonaro’s—including the outright defiance of court mandates. But like Bolsonaro, Trump and his administration have not sought constitutional change or legislative avenues to override the authority or independence of America’s judiciary.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Similarly, though Trump has bypassed Congress through various evasive maneuvers, he has not rewritten the rules of legislative procedure or implemented structural changes to constrain the legislature. This sets the United States apart from the other presidential cases in this study, like Ecuador, in which illiberal leadership fundamentally altered legislative institutions, functionally eliminating their capacities to constrain the executive. While a Republican-led Congress might not present meaningful checks on Trump’s executive actions out of party loyalty, the lack of institutional weakening may provide avenues for democratic pushback or recovery down the road.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><blockquote>While a Republican-led Congress might not present meaningful checks on Trump’s executive actions out of party loyalty, the lack of institutional weakening may provide avenues for democratic pushback or recovery down the road.</blockquote></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The Trump administration’s efforts to weaken societal constraints on the executive have also been characterized by a lower degree of institutionalization compared to other executive aggrandizement cases. For example, a common tactic among backsliding leaders is their use of legal restrictions on civil society organizations or individuals to dampen societal pushback or constraints. In Ecuador, Correa’s allies passed laws in 2013 that mandated that organizations report on their activities to the government, banned “partisan activities,” and shut down groups that participated in advocacy against government policies.<sup class="footnote">91</sup> In India, Modi’s government has cracked down on societal dissent, relying on sedition laws and restrictions on free speech to police its public.<sup class="footnote">92</sup> This has not yet been the case in the United States. The Trump administration’s targeting of individuals, law firms, and universities has undeniably had a chilling effect on public institutions and civil society groups—and there are worries that legal restrictions might still emerge. But as of now, U.S. civil society remains free of broad restrictions and vertical accountability remains a viable check on executive power.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The Trump administration’s tactics to repress critical media reflect a similar overall pattern as found in other backsliding regimes but are not yet as institutionalized as in other cases. Trump and his team have targeted certain news sites with investigations and lawsuits, restricted press groups from accessing government events, and repeatedly attacked or criticized journalists and news organizations. Several of these tactics do echo cases like El Salvador, Hungary, Poland, and Türkiye, where backsliding leadership frequently delegitimized the press and used strategic lawsuits to weaken independent outlets. But in comparison to such cases, the Trump administration has not gone as far in its efforts to legally constrain or co-opt independent media. Under the Fidesz administration in Hungary, for example, the government acquired media companies and compiled them under the Central European Press and Media Foundation in 2018, ensuring that pro-government coverage dominated the country’s media ecosystem. In Poland, too, gaining control over the country’s largest public media companies gave PiS the ability to skew coverage of the administration and was a difficult institutional change for the subsequent administration to untangle.<sup class="footnote">93</sup> In Türkiye, the Erdoğan government used legal punishment to silence critical press and pushed for the sale of media outlets to pro-government companies.<sup class="footnote">94</sup> Whether the Trump administration will succeed in codifying such restrictions remains to be seen, but U.S. media is less structurally constrained or imperiled than in other important cases.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The emphasis that the Trump administration has placed on restructuring the executive branch is an exception to this overall low level of institutionalization. However, even in this domain, the Trump administration has not formalized its changes through legislative or constitutional changes. Instead, his team has primarily employed a combination of personnel changes and procedural shifts. To target federal agencies focused on oversight and accountability, for example, Trump fired leadership at the Office of Special Counsel, the Office of Government Ethics, the National Labor Relations Board, the Federal Trade Commission, and others. And he has used executive orders to mandate greater White House oversight of independent executive agencies, to change procedures to make it easier to fire civil servants, and to politicize the federal hiring process.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>In the common backsliding model, this subjugation of executive agencies and workers is often enshrined in more formal ways. Türkiye is an extreme example, where Erdoğan’s AKP party successfully amended the Constitution in 2017 to formalize presidential dominance over the executive branch. These changes eliminated the prime minister role, establishing the Turkish president as head of both the state and executive, expanding his power to unilaterally select his officials without parliamentary oversight, and granting him the authority to shape the executive branch and create new ministries.<sup class="footnote">95</sup> In countries like Hungary and Poland, too, efforts to cement the new leadership’s control over civil servants and the state administration were enacted through legislation.<sup class="footnote">96</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Across the three levels of the Trump administration’s aggrandizement project, democratic erosion has not become as deeply rooted as it has in many other backsliding cases. In the years to come, it remains to be seen whether the administration will seek to and succeed in more firmly institutionalizing its executive aggrandizement, or if U.S. checks and balances will prevent it from doing so.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h4>Limited Repressive Measures</h4></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The degree of repression inflicted on political and civic opponents by the Trump administration is lower than what occurred in most of the comparison cases. On one hand, through their retributive actions and rhetoric, and their constant use of extreme political language, Trump and his team have contributed significantly to an increasingly retributive U.S. political culture. Trump has, for example, persistently attacked judges and other elected officials, and research has found that such comments have coincided with “escalating violent posts on social media,” where threats of violence and calls for impeachment against judges have risen “327 percent between May 2024 and March 2025.”<sup class="footnote">97</sup> But the administration has not widely used coercive force or criminalization to sideline political opposition, silence critical media, or dampen societal pushback.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>In contrast, Erdoğan’s government collaborated with allied prosecutors, judges, and police to arrest more than 700 people between 2007 and 2012—from military officers to academics and journalists—on fabricated charges of plotting a coup.<sup class="footnote">98</sup> In subsequent years, the AKP has also imprisoned major opposition figures, including opposition presidential candidate Selahattin Demirtaş in 2016 and Istanbul mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu in 2025, thus pushing Türkiye toward full authoritarianism.<sup class="footnote">99</sup> In El Salvador, Bukele leveraged his emergency powers to deploy the military and curtail civil liberties in 2022. His forces cracked down on civilians, resulting in widespread imprisonment and violence.<sup class="footnote">100</sup> In Brazil, Bolsonaro greatly eroded civil-military boundaries, giving the military deep influence over government institutions, cultivating a militarized civic culture, and empowering the military to engage in aggressive policing tactics throughout the country.<sup class="footnote">101</sup> Other backsliding cases beyond the focal set of this study, such as Myanmar, Nicaragua, and Venezuela, have involved overt and pervasive political violence.<sup class="footnote">102</sup></p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Thus far, the U.S. case more closely resembles countries where elite-led polarization has contributed to increasingly violent political cultures more than it has produced overt government repression—like India, where Modi’s Hindu nationalist agenda has fomented deepening sectarian polarization and vigilantism within Indian society.<sup class="footnote">103</sup> Of course, it is still early into the administration, and other backsliding leaders often only initiated more violent tactics later into their backsliding drives. Most worrisome in this regard have been the administration’s extremely harsh tactics in its deportation policies, and the almost reflexive militarization of its response to protests on that issue.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h3>Conclusions</h3></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>President Donald Trump’s effort to consolidate executive dominance over all parts of the U.S. political system parallels the campaigns of executive aggrandizement carried out by autocratically inclined elected leaders in numerous other countries in recent years. At the same time, some of Trump’s key tactics—such as dominating and weakening the executive branch, delegitimizing and circumventing horizontal institutions, and leveraging funding and procedural restrictions against sites of societal pushback—are less common in other cases, where executives assume automatic acquiescence from executive agencies and bureaucracy, handily disempower the legislature and judiciary through constitutional changes, or push through laws that criminalize dissent and restrict civil society’s freedoms. Facing the strong institutional constraints and norms that underpin U.S. democracy, Trump’s team cannot simply follow the exact same backsliding playbook that has served executives in weaker or less consolidated democracies around the world. Instead, it must target checks and balances that are unique to the American system, using the narrower set of tools that are available to a U.S. president.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Nevertheless, the aggressiveness of Trump’s executive aggrandizement is worrisome. Despite the relative strength of U.S. democratic constraints, Trump has pursued his agenda with a speed that outpaces even some of the most rapid cases of democratic erosion, like Hungary and Poland. And compared to the backsliding approaches taken in countries ranging from Ecuador to India, the Trump team’s approach has been more immediate and expansive than is common. It may seem comforting that despite this rapidity, U.S. democratic backsliding is still less institutionalized or overtly repressive than many other backsliding cases. But in light of the high barriers to democratic erosion in the United States, what makes the current context especially troubling is not the relative extremity of Trump’s executive aggrandizement, but how fast and systematically he has achieved these aims within a democratic system once thought to be impervious.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>It remains to be seen how far Trump intends to go in his aggrandizement agenda. But assessing the U.S. case in comparative analysis helps make sense of the constraints facing the administration and the pathways available to it moving forward. These conclusions start to provide lines of analysis for those who are focused on how to respond. Pushback against the administration’s strenuous, multipronged effort at executive aggrandizement, for example, will only be systematically effective if it is at least somewhat coordinated across multiple sectors and meets the Trump administration’s simultaneous assault across different political levels with a parallel set of multilevel efforts at constraint.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Additionally, while Trump has sought to project immense power by shattering so many democratic norms so quickly, the focal areas of his drive reveal that his administration still faces numerous constraints within U.S. democracy that pro-democracy actors can and should leverage, including 1) an executive branch that still has internal accountability mechanisms and constraints on unfettered presidential power, 2) a legal system that makes constitutional change very difficult, 3) a legislature with many veto points, and 4) a well-resourced private sector, a historically independent media sector, and a comparatively well-resourced nonprofit sector.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Finally, the comparative perspective highlights that U.S. democratic backsliding is not yet deeply rooted or severe, leaving significant space for pro-democracy actors to engage. But these responses must come soon, be sustained, and be ready to weather worse times ahead. As the Trump administration continues to amass power around a president driven by a reflexive intolerance toward criticism and opposition and a willingness to try to overturn any norm, process, or institution in his path, the deep roots of American democracy will be put to a full test in the months and years ahead.</p></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><h3>Acknowledgments</h3></div><!--]--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The Carnegie Endowment’s Democracy, Conflict, and Governance Program is grateful to the Hewlett Foundation for financial support that helped make the research for and writing of this paper possible. The authors thank Rachel Kleinfeld, Jennifer McCoy, and Andrew O’Donohue for comments and suggestions on a draft. The contents of the paper are the responsibility of the authors alone.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></div></div><!--]--><div class="footnotes-list" data-v-9b8d7a34="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><h3 data-v-e4fa124b="">Notes</h3><ul data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-1"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>1</sup>Kurt Weyland, “Right-Wing Populism in the USA: Trump in Comparative Perspective,” in <em>Democracy's Resilience to Populism's Threat: Countering Global Alarmism</em> (Cambridge University Press, 2024), 196-226, <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Democracys-Resilience-Populisms-Threat-Countering/dp/100943246X" rel="">https://www.amazon.com/Democracys-Resilience-Populisms-Threat-Countering/dp/100943246X</a>; Asli Aydintasbas, “Trump Can’t Be Dictator on ‘Day One’ — Or in a Second Term. Here’s Why,” POLITICO, January 28, 2024, <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2024/01/28/a-trump-dictatorship-is-possible-but-not-in-four-years-00137949" rel="">https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2024/01/28/a-trump-dictatorship-is-possible-but-not-in-four-years-00137949</a>; Rachel Beatty Riedl, “Pathways of Democratic Backsliding, Resistance, and (Partial) Recoveries,” <em>The ANNALS of the American Academy of Political and Social Science </em>712, no. 1 (March 2025): 9-31, <a href="https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/epub/10.1177/00027162251319909" rel="">https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/epub/10.1177/00027162251319909</a>; and Thomas Carothers, “Lessons About Backsliding and Resistance,” <em>The ANNALS of the American Academy of Political and Social Science </em>712, no. 1 (March 2025): 250-257, <a href="https://doi.org/10.1177/00027162251316344" rel="">https://doi.org/10.1177/00027162251316344</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-7"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>7</sup>Thomas Carothers and Benjamin Press, “Understanding and Responding to Global Democratic Backsliding,” Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, October 20, 2022, <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2022/10/understanding-and-responding-to-global-democratic-backsliding?lang=en" rel="">https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2022/10/understanding-and-responding-to-global-democratic-backsliding?lang=en</a>;</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-8"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>8</sup>Thomas Carothers and McKenzie Carrier, “Democratic Recovery After Significant Backsliding: Emergent Lessons,” Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, April 28, 2025, <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2025/04/democratic-recovery-after-significant-backsliding-emergent-lessons?lang=en" rel="">https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2025/04/democratic-recovery-after-significant-backsliding-emergent-lessons?lang=en</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-9"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>9</sup>Cass R. Sunstein, “This Theory Is Behind Trump’s Power Grab,” <em>New York Times</em>, February 26, 2025, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/26/opinion/trump-roberts-unitary-executive-theory.html" rel="">https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/26/opinion/trump-roberts-unitary-executive-theory.html</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-10"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>10</sup>Meryl Kornfield and Lisa Rein, “Trump Oversight Picks Include Scandal-Hit Ex-Lawmaker, Antiabortion Lawyer,” <em>Washington Post</em>, May 29, 2025, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/28/trump-inspectors-general-scandal-partisan/" rel="">https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/28/trump-inspectors-general-scandal-partisan/</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-11"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>11</sup>Stephen Fowler, “Judge grants top whistleblower advocate reprieve after he sued Trump over firing,” NPR, February 10, 2025, <a href="https://www.npr.org/2025/02/10/nx-s1-5292259/hampton-dellinger-trump-special-counsel" rel="">https://www.npr.org/2025/02/10/nx-s1-5292259/hampton-dellinger-trump-special-counsel</a>; and Kathryn Watson, “Trump Ousts Director of Office of Government Ethics,” CBS News, February 10, 2025, <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-office-of-government-ethics-director/" rel="">https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-office-of-government-ethics-director/</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-12"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>12</sup>Will Weissert, “Trump Has Canceled Biden’s Ethics Rules. Roberts (Cambridge University Press, 2025), <a href="https://milanvaishnav.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/backsliding_in_india-final.pdf" rel="">https://milanvaishnav.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/backsliding_in_india-final.pdf</a>.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-93"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>93</sup>Carothers and Carrier, "Democratic Recovery After Significant Backsliding."</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></li><li data-v-e4fa124b="" id="footnote-94"><div class="body-style-serif-large theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements" data-v-daf0800a="" data-v-e4fa124b=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p><sup>94</sup>Max Hoffman and Michael Werz, “Freedom of the Press and Expression in Turkey,” Center for American Progress, May 14, 2013, <a href="https://www.americanprogress.org/article/freedom-of-the-press-and-expression-in-turkey/" rel="">https://www.americanprogress.org/article/freedom-of-the-press-and-expression-in-turkey/</a>; class="aside-block" data-v-11e4b2ca="" data-v-a391c75a=""><!-- --><!--[--><!--[--><div class="--color-context-white affiliation-card card" data-v-6a52938a="" data-v-a391c75a=""><div typography opacity-dark eyebrow card-eyebrow" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-55c50705="" data-v-6a52938a=""><!--[--><!--[-->program <!--]--><!--]--></h6><a class="anchor" data-v-6a52938a="" href="/programs/democracy-conflict-and-governance?lang=en"><!--[--><h2 class="h4-display direction-ltr typography heading" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-6a52938a=""><!--[-->Democracy, Conflict, and Governance<!--]--></h2><!--]--></a><div class="body-style-serif-small theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements dek" data-v-6a52938a="" data-v-daf0800a=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>The Democracy, Conflict, and Governance Program is a leading source of independent policy research, writing, and outreach on global democracy, conflict, and governance. It analyzes and seeks to improve international efforts to reduce democratic backsliding, mitigate conflict and violence, overcome political polarization, promote gender equality, and advance pro-democratic uses of new technologies.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><a class="anchor button-tertiary theme-light size-regular icon-position-right button cta" data-v-2387f140="" data-v-6a52938a="" href="/programs/democracy-conflict-and-governance?lang=en" style=""><!--[--><span class="label direction-ltr typography label" data-v-2387f140="" data-v-239cd353=""><!--[--><!--[-->Learn More<!--]--><!--]--></span><!-- --><!--[--><!--]--><!--]--></a></div></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--><!--]--></div></aside><div class="main-center" data-v-31ab6e94=""><!--[--><!--]--></div><aside Program<!--]--></p></div><!-- --></div></li><li class="author" data-v-a391c75a=""><div class="person-list-item" data-v-47de8580="" data-v-a391c75a="" isinline="true" size="33"><div Fineberg Chair for Democracy Studies; Director, Democracy, Conflict, and Governance Program<!--]--></p></div><div class="size-default avatar" data-v-47de8580="" data-v-fb741989="" path="/people/thomas-carothers?lang=en"><span class="avatar" data-v-fb741989=""><!--[--><img __typename="Avatar" class="image desaturate" data-v-753462ba="" data-v-fb741989="" height="1276" id="66319d307f250831f168924a" mimetype="image/jpeg" sizes="" src="https://carnegie-production-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/static/media/avatars/Carothers-Thomas-Headshot.jpg" srcset="" width="1000"/><!--]--></span></div></div></li><!--]--></ul><!--]--></div><!--]--><!--]--><!--]--></aside></section></div><span data-v-1e205e4f=""></span></div><section class="footer" data-v-1e205e4f=""><!--[--><section class="top-padding-extra bottom-padding-standard background-grey tier related-content-tier" data-v-a391c75a="" data-v-e231f7e4="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="inner" data-v-e231f7e4=""><!-- --><!--[--><div class="wrapper" data-v-f3f38b68=""><h2 class="h4-display direction-ltr typography heading" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><!--[-->More work from Carnegie<!--]--></h2><ul class="content-items" data-v-f3f38b68=""><!--[--><!--[--><li class="content-item" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="context-inline size-50 orientation-wide background-color-grey content-card-block" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="main" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="image-collage visual" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="" class="image" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-753462ba="" height="770" id="68ac50b0d7092b05eb16bf17" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/GettyImages-2222815183%20CROP.jpg" srcset="" width="1420"/></div><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="A crowd of Sri Lankan protesters hold Sri Lankan flags. One man stands atop a pickup truck on the left side of the frame." class="image" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-753462ba="" height="770" id="68af35a211220e9f5b7a12b8" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/Sri-Lanka-protest-democratic-movement-GettyImages-1407702670.jpg" srcset="" width="1420"/></div><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="President Donald Trump speaks to the media as he departs the White House on August 01, 2025 in Washington, DC. This collection includes the most in-depth research from Carnegie scholars. </p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--></div><div class="last-row credits" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!-- --><!-- --><!-- --></div></div></div></div><!-- --></div></li><!--]--><!--[--><li class="content-item" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="context-inline size-50 orientation-wide background-color-grey content-card-block" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="main" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="visual" data-v-1dc671f0=""><a class="anchor" data-v-1dc671f0="" href="/research/2025/09/moldovas-election-is-a-test-for-russian-influence-in-europe?lang=en"><!--[--><img alt="Moldova Election Russia Europe" class="image article image" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-753462ba="" height="770" id="68d641d73c7f56473a868e99" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/Moldova%20Election%20Russia%20Europe%20-1229973170.jpg" srcset="" width="1420"/><!--]--></a></div><!--]--><div class="theme-light content-summary summary" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!-- --><div class="summary-wrapper" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="meta" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="--teal type-label type-label" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><span class="label-small direction-ltr typography text" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><!--[-->article<!--]--></span></div><!-- --></div><a class="anchor" data-v-3af52fd8="" href="/research/2025/09/moldovas-election-is-a-test-for-russian-influence-in-europe?lang=en"><!--[--><div class="heading" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="h5 direction-ltr typography heading" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-239cd353=""><!--[-->Moldova’s Election Is a Test for Russian Influence in Europe<!--]--></div><!--]--></div><!--]--></a><!-- --><div class="description" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="body-style-serif-small theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements description" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-daf0800a=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Moldova’s parliamentary election is make-or-break for the country’s European future. The outcome will test whether Chișinău will stay on the EU accession path or fall prey to Russia’s multi-domain interference campaign.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--></div><div class="last-row credits" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="theme-light avatar-set" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><ul class="avatars" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><!--[--><li class="person" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><div class="size-small avatar" data-v-ccb37f94="" data-v-fb741989=""><span class="avatar" data-v-fb741989=""><!--[--><img alt="" class="image desaturate" data-v-753462ba="" data-v-fb741989="" height="950" id="663b91558b7de23b97403a6f" sizes="" src="/static/media/avatars/Oana_Popescu-Zamfir__1___1___1_-8.jpg" srcset="" width="950"/><!--]--></span></div><!--]--></li><!--]--><!--]--></ul><ul class="names" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><li class="name" data-v-ccb37f94=""><span class="body-micro direction-ltr typography" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><span data-v-ccb37f94="">Oana Popescu-Zamfir</span><!-- --><!--]--></span></li><!--]--></ul></div><!-- --><!-- --></div></div></div></div><!-- --></div></li><!--]--><!--[--><li class="content-item" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="context-inline size-50 orientation-wide background-color-grey content-card-block" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="main" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="image-collage visual" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="A man uses his smartphone as he sits on a sidewalk in Ho Chi Minh City on December 23, 2024. S" class="image" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-753462ba="" height="770" id="68b9eb762785017cd9c0171b" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/democracy-expertise-communication-GettyImages-2190544372.jpg" srcset="" width="1420"/></div><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="" class="image" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-753462ba="" height="770" id="66428c816c4e6d6055d9936c" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/in-the-media-1.jpg" srcset="" width="1420"/></div><div class="piece" data-v-0cd167ea=""><img alt="" class="image" data-v-0cd167ea="" data-v-753462ba="" height="" sizes="" src="/static-images/in-the-media.jpg" srcset="" width=""/></div><!--]--></div><!--]--><div class="theme-light content-summary summary" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!-- --><div class="summary-wrapper" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="meta" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="--tan type-label type-label" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><span class="label-small direction-ltr typography text" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><!--[-->collection<!--]--></span></div><!-- --></div><a class="anchor" data-v-3af52fd8="" href="/programs/democracy-conflict-and-governance/us-democracy-in-comparative-perspective?lang=en"><!--[--><div class="heading" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="h5 direction-ltr typography heading" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-239cd353=""><!--[-->U.S. Democracy in Comparative Perspective<!--]--></div><!--]--></div><!--]--></a><!-- --><div class="description" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="body-style-serif-small theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements description" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-daf0800a=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>In recent years, multiple international indices have downgraded U.S. democracy.  Polarization, accusations of voting irregularities, political violence, and other negative trends are having a corrosive influence on the state of U.S. democracy and leaders’ ability to govern, address domestic problems, and craft stable policies.  This project brings together the work of scholars across the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who analyze the problems afflicting U.S. democracy based on comparative perspectives and offer insights that can strengthen U.S. governing institutions and society.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--></div><div class="last-row credits" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="theme-light avatar-set" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><ul class="avatars" data-v-f4f46db8=""><span class="label-small direction-ltr typography text" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><!--[-->article<!--]--></span></div><!-- --></div><a class="anchor" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-239cd353=""><!--[-->U.S. Political Interventionism Under Trump<!--]--></div><!--]--></div><!--]--></a><!-- --><div class="description" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="body-style-serif-small theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements description" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-daf0800a=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Despite promising not to lecture other countries on “how to live,” the Trump administration is intervening with increasing frequency and force in the political affairs of other countries.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--></div><div class="last-row credits" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="theme-light avatar-set" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><ul class="avatars" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><li class="name" data-v-ccb37f94=""><span class="body-micro direction-ltr typography" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><a class="anchor" data-v-ccb37f94="" href="/people/thomas-carothers?lang=en"><!--[-->Thomas Carothers<!--]--></a><!--[-->, <!--]--><!--]--></span></li><li class="name" data-v-ccb37f94=""><span class="body-micro direction-ltr typography" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><a class="anchor" data-v-ccb37f94="" href="/people/oliver-stuenkel?lang=en"><!--[-->Oliver Stuenkel<!--]--></a><!-- --><!--]--></span></li><!--]--></ul></div><!-- --><!-- --></div></div></div></div><!-- --></div></li><!--]--><!--[--><li class="content-item" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="context-inline size-50 orientation-wide background-color-grey content-card-block" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-f3f38b68=""><div class="main" data-v-1dc671f0=""><!--[--><div class="report visual" data-v-1dc671f0=""><a class="anchor" data-v-1dc671f0="" href="/research/2025/09/preventing-nuclear-anarchy-nuclear-proliferation-and-american-security?lang=en"><!--[--><img alt="Preventing an Era of Nuclear Anarchy report cover" class="image report image" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-753462ba="" height="1440" id="68c1da54720891d4b1fb2ee6" sizes="" src="/static/media/images/Preventing-an-Era-of-Nuclear-Anarchy-cover.jpg" srcset="" width="1008"/><!--]--></a></div><!--]--><div class="theme-light content-summary summary" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!-- --><div class="summary-wrapper" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="meta" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="--teal type-label type-label" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><span class="label-small direction-ltr typography text" data-v-239cd353="" data-v-f4f46db8=""><!--[-->report<!--]--></span></div><!-- --></div><a class="anchor" data-v-3af52fd8="" href="/research/2025/09/preventing-nuclear-anarchy-nuclear-proliferation-and-american-security?lang=en"><!--[--><div class="heading" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="h5 direction-ltr typography heading" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-239cd353=""><!--[-->Preventing an Era of Nuclear Anarchy: Nuclear Proliferation and American Security<!--]--></div><!--]--></div><!--]--></a><!-- --><div class="description" data-v-3af52fd8=""><!--[--><div class="body-style-serif-small theme-light size-50 rich-text-elements description" data-v-1dc671f0="" data-v-daf0800a=""><!--[--><!--[--><div class="rich-text" data-v-daf0800a=""><p>Following decades of mostly successful efforts to combat the spread of nuclear weapons, multiple global trends are reviving the possibility of a world with more nuclear-armed states. These developments raise fundamental questions about whether the United States can and should prioritize efforts to stymie further acquisition of nuclear weapons in the twenty-first century.</p></div><!--]--><!--]--></div><!--]--></div><div class="last-row credits" data-v-3af52fd8=""><div class="theme-light avatar-set" data-v-3af52fd8="" data-v-ccb37f94=""><ul class="avatars" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><!--[--><li class="person" data-v-ccb37f94=""><!--[--><div class="size-small avatar" data-v-ccb37f94="" data-v-fb741989=""><span class="avatar" data-v-fb741989=""><!--[--><a :754,"text":1024,"type":756,"version":757},"In recent years, multiple international indices have downgraded U.S. democracy.  Polarization, accusations of voting irregularities, political violence, and other negative trends are having a corrosive Endowment for International Peace who analyze the problems afflicting U.S. democracy based on comparative perspectives and offer insights that can strengthen U.S. governing institutions and Content","tags","original-content","2023-12-08T10:53:54.573Z",{"en":739,"ar":739,"ru":739,"hi":739,"zh":739,"es":739,"de":739,"fr":739,"th":739},"hidden","Tag",{"root":1622},{"children":1623,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1624],{"children":1625,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1626],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1627,"type":756,"version":757},"The erosion of U.S. democracy under President Donald Trump shares many features with other prominent cases of democratic backsliding. Yet a close comparative look highlights important distinctive elements of Trump’s approach.",{"image":1629,"__typename":1631},{"url":1630,"altText":889,"caption":760,"width":851,"height":852,"__typename":811},"https://carnegie-production-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/static/media/images/trump-democracy-GettyImages-2228103890.jpg","Research_Hero",[1633,1710,1749],{"blockName":760,"blockType":1634,"richText":1635,"__typename":1709},"richTextBlock",{"root":1636},{"children":1637,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1638,1644,1648,1652,1681,1685,1705],{"children":1639,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[1640],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1641,"type":756,"version":757},"Summary","heading","h3",{"children":1645,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1646],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1647,"type":756,"version":757},"The global democratic recession of the past twenty years has been marked by numerous cases of elected leaders incrementally dismantling democracy through a steady centralization of power and undercutting of checks and balances—what political scientists label as executive aggrandizement. Under the second Donald Trump presidency, the United States is showing clear signs of following such a path, leading many commenters to draw arresting but often relatively glancing comparisons with other prominent recent cases of democratic erosion, like Hungary, India, Poland, and Türkiye. This paper examines U.S. political developments since the return of Trump to power in an in-depth, comparative light, seeking to illuminate the similarities and differences between the unfolding U.S. context and the experience of other troubled democracies.",{"children":1649,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1650],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1651,"type":756,"version":757},"The paper establishes that the Trump administration’s overall political project conforms to the general model of executive aggrandizement, and is best understood as taking place at three interrelated levels:",{"children":1653,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1678,"version":757,"listType":1679,"start":757,"tag":1680},[1654,1661,1671],{"children":1655,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":757},[1656,1658],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1657,"type":756,"version":757},"Establishing the president as supreme within the executive branch",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1659,"type":756,"version":757},": Trump’s team seeks an extreme form of presidential concentration of power within the executive branch. It has weakened accountability institutions and regulations, tightened presidential control over independent agencies and the executive bureaucracy, decreased the political independence of the civil service, and purged perceived opponents from the branch.","listitem",{"children":1662,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":1544},[1663,1665,1667,1669],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1664,"type":756,"version":757},"Making the executive branch dominant over other parts of government",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1666,"type":756,"version":757},":",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1668,"type":756,"version":757}," ",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1670,"type":756,"version":757},"The administration is forcefully seeking dominance over the judiciary, Congress, and states. It has defied court orders, criticized judicial rulings, and constrained individual judges. It has circumvented congressional policies and undermined its powers. And it has attacked and constrained state governments that do not align with administration policies.",{"children":1672,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":1677},[1673,1675],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1674,"type":756,"version":757},"Weakening societal constraints on executive power",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1676,"type":756,"version":757},": Trump has stymied civil society opposition by attacking independent media, punishing lawyers and law firms perceived to be oppositional, and constraining civic and educational organizations. His team has undermined vertical checks on the executive by weakening voting rights and the independence of election administration. Broadly, Trump is pursuing widespread retribution against perceived opponents and critics.",3,"list","number","ol",{"children":1682,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1683],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1684,"type":756,"version":757},"The paper then compares the path of U.S. politics under Trump to seven other recent or ongoing cases of democratic backsliding—Brazil, Ecuador, El Salvador, Hungary, India, Poland, and Türkiye—highlighting distinctive features along three comparative dimensions:",{"children":1686,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1678,"version":757,"listType":1679,"start":757,"tag":1680},[1687,1693,1699],{"children":1688,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":757},[1689,1691],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1690,"type":756,"version":757},"Focus",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1692,"type":756,"version":757},": The Trump team’s agenda has several priorities that set it apart from other backsliding cases. These include its unique emphasis on intra-executive dominance, delegitimization rather than institutionalized attacks on horizontal checks, and coercive use of the robust federal funding ecosystem to pressure U.S. civil society.",{"children":1694,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":1544},[1695,1697],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1696,"type":756,"version":757},"Rapidity",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1698,"type":756,"version":757},": The administration has carried out its political program with striking speed. Compared to other backsliding cases, it has sought to centralize power with greater momentum and rapidity. And while other leaders often eroded democratic checks piece by piece, Trump’s team is working to weaken such checks across multiple levels all at once.",{"children":1700,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1660,"version":757,"value":1677},[1701,1703],{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1702,"type":756,"version":757},"Severity",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1704,"type":756,"version":757},": The degree of democratic erosion in the United States is not yet as severe as that of most of its backsliding peers. The country has not yet seen the deep-rooted institutional changes that have characterized many of the comparative cases. And repressive measures like coercive force or criminalization have been limited by U.S. democratic norms and institutions.",{"children":1706,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1707],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1708,"type":756,"version":757},"While some comfort can be taken from the fact that the relatively deeply rooted U.S. democratic norms and institutions compared to those in the other cases have resulted in a less institutionalized process of backsliding thus far, the distinctive speed and aggressiveness of Trump’s aggrandizement agenda is cause for serious concern. Numerous avenues and sources of resistance to democratic erosion continue to exist, but U.S. democracy is being put to the test as never before in the country’s modern democracy.","quote",{"children":1833,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1834,1836,1861,1863],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1835,"type":756,"version":757},"Political observers and scholars are debating the severity of this threat to democracy. Some believe that the United States is on the verge of losing its liberal democracy altogether and has already in fact slipped into the category of what political scientists have come to call competitive authoritarian regimes. They argue that checks and balances are actively failing, that the administration is reflexively intolerant of opposition, and that it is openly violating the Constitution and other laws.",{"type":1766,"footnote":1837,"version":757},{"root":1838},{"children":1839,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1840],{"children":1841,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1842,1844,1846,1848,1853,1855,1860],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1843,"type":756,"version":757},"Laura Gamboa, “How to Save a Democracy,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1845,"type":756,"version":757},"Foreign Affairs",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1847,"type":756,"version":757},", March 31, 2025, ",{"children":1849,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1852},[1850],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1851,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.foreignaffairs.com/united-states/how-save-democracy-trump?check_logged_in=1",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1851},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1854,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Larry Diamond, “The Crisis of Democracy Is Here,” Persuasion, February 17, 2025, ",{"children":1856,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1859},[1857],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1858,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.persuasion.community/p/the-crisis-of-democracy-is-here?utm_source=profile&utm_medium=reader2",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1858},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1862,"type":756,"version":757}," Others are more optimistic. Here’s Why,” POLITICO, January 28, 2024, ",{"children":1883,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1886},[1884],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1885,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2024/01/28/a-trump-dictatorship-is-possible-but-not-in-four-years-00137949",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1885},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1888,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Abdallah Fayyad, “Three Reasons Why American Democracy Will Likely Withstand Trump,” Vox, February 26, 2025, ",{"children":1890,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1893},[1891],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1892,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.vox.com/politics/401247/american-democracy-resilient-trump-authoritarian",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1892},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":1896,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1897,1899,1913],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1898,"type":756,"version":757},"Participants in this debate, especially those on the more pessimistic end of the scale, often invoke cases from other countries as evidence for their views. They argue that many of Trump’s actions since January 2025 strongly resemble those by leaders of other countries where democracy has been significantly eroded, that Trump is operating from the same “autocratic playbook” that elected leaders in many other countries have utilized to dismantle democracy.",{"type":1766,"footnote":1900,"version":757},{"root":1901},{"children":1902,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1903],{"children":1904,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1905,1907,1912],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1906,"type":756,"version":757},"Scott Cummings, “Stopping Autocratic Legalism in America – Before It Is Too Late,” Verfassungsblog, March 26, 2025, ",{"children":1908,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1911},[1909],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1910,"type":756,"version":757},"https://verfassungsblog.de/stopping-autocratic-legalism-in-america-before-it-is-too-late/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1910},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1914,"type":756,"version":757}," Comparisons to democratic erosion in Hungary under Viktor Orbán, in India under Narendra Modi, in Poland under the Law and Justice party, in Türkiye under Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, and in Brazil under Jair Bolsonaro are especially common. While these and other country comparisons are potentially valuable, they are often injected into U.S. debates in shorthand fashion, like political flashcards rather than in-depth illuminations. This paper seeks to go deeper, to probe the comparative angle on U.S. democratic backsliding in some detail, with a view to providing new insights about the Trump administration’s political project.",{"children":1916,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1917],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1918,"type":756,"version":757},"The paper proceeds as follows. It first outlines what has emerged globally in the past twenty years as a general model of democratic backsliding: executive aggrandizement—an incremental, executive-led amassing and consolidation of power at the top of a political system that undermines democratic constraints and suffocates democratic freedoms. It then identifies and analyzes the main elements of the Trump administration’s approach. It finds that Trump has pursued three main levels of executive aggrandizement—weakening checks on executive power from within the executive branch, subverting horizontal accountability institutions, and undermining societal constraints on the president.",{"children":1920,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1921],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1922,"type":756,"version":757},"The paper then brings in the comparative perspective. It examines the U.S. context along three dimensions of executive aggrandizement—focal areas, rapidity, and severity—comparing it to a set of prominent recent or ongoing cases of backsliding in Europe, Latin America, and South Asia. While Trump’s agenda broadly aligns with the common backsliding model, it also diverges in notable ways. Constrained by the institutional guardrails on the president and government that exist within the U.S. democratic system, the administration has focused on subverting, delegitimizing, and coercing the different checks on Trump’s authority rather than seeking the institutionalized democratic erosion more common among backsliding peers. Trump has pursued executive aggrandizement with greater speed and aggression than most other backsliding leaders, yet U.S. democratic erosion is not, at least so far, as severe as in a number of other backsliding cases.",{"children":1924,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1925],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1926,"type":756,"version":757},"While the continued resilience of U.S. democracy to date may offer some reassurance, the fact that backsliding in the United States has come this far so fast signals the seriousness and urgency of the ongoing threat to democracy. It remains unclear how much further the Trump administration will go with its executive aggrandizement in the next few years, but understanding the U.S. case in global context provides useful perspective about what may lie ahead.",{"children":1928,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[1929],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1930,"type":756,"version":757},"The Common Backsliding Model       ",{"children":1932,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1933,1935,1974,1976,1991],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1934,"type":756,"version":757},"Comparative studies of the ongoing global trend of democratic backsliding highlight a high degree of similarity in the basic political method at work—what analysts label as executive aggrandizement or executive overreach.",{"type":1766,"footnote":1936,"version":757},{"root":1937},{"children":1938,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1939],{"children":1940,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1941,1943,1945,1947,1952,1954,1956,1958,1963,1965,1966,1968,1973],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1942,"type":756,"version":757},"Nancy Bermeo, “On Democratic Backsliding,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},"Journal of Democracy",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1946,"type":756,"version":757}," 27, no. 1 (January 2016): 5-19, ",{"children":1948,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1951},[1949],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1950,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/on-democratic-backsliding/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1950},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1953,"type":756,"version":757},"; Rachel Beatty Riedl, “Pathways of Democratic Backsliding, Resistance, and (Partial) Recoveries,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1955,"type":756,"version":757},"The ANNALS of the American Academy of Political and Social Science ",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1957,"type":756,"version":757},"712, no. 1 (March 2025): 9-31, ",{"children":1959,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1962},[1960],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1961,"type":756,"version":757},"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/epub/10.1177/00027162251319909",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1961},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1964,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Thomas Carothers, “Lessons About Backsliding and Resistance,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1955,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1967,"type":756,"version":757},"712, no. 1 (March 2025): 250-257, ",{"children":1969,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1972},[1970],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1971,"type":756,"version":757},"https://doi.org/10.1177/00027162251316344",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1971},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1975,"type":756,"version":757}," Employing this method, elected leaders with antidemocratic intent amass a preponderance of power by undermining all major constraints on their power, whether in the form of horizontal or vertical lines of accountability. Common tactics include weakening the independent judiciary and legislature, politicizing and weaponizing prosecutorial power, undermining the fairness of the electoral process, censoring or harassing independent media, co-opting private businesses, and undercutting the independence of civil society. Executive aggrandizement contrasts with forms of democratic erosion that used to dominate cases of backsliding, such as military coups, or other forms of abrupt, authoritarian takeovers.",{"type":1766,"footnote":1977,"version":757},{"root":1978},{"children":1979,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[1980],{"children":1981,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1982,1984,1989],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1983,"type":756,"version":757},"Thomas Carothers and Benjamin Press, “Understanding and Responding to Global Democratic Backsliding,” Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, October 20, 2022, ",{"children":1985,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":1988},[1986],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1987,"type":756,"version":757},"https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2022/10/understanding-and-responding-to-global-democratic-backsliding?lang=en",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":1987},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1990,"type":756,"version":757},";",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1992,"type":756,"version":757}," It involves leaders who have been fairly elected acting incrementally, wielding existing political processes and institutions to erode democratic norms and structures step by step, usually while characterizing their actions as reforms needed to strengthen or purify democracy.",{"children":1994,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[1995,1997,2011],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1996,"type":756,"version":757},"Despite the strong commonalities of this model across most of the main cases of democratic backsliding in recent years, variations exist along at least three axes.",{"type":1766,"footnote":1998,"version":757},{"root":1999},{"children":2000,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[2001],{"children":2002,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[2003,2005,2010],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2004,"type":756,"version":757},"Thomas Carothers and McKenzie Carrier, “Democratic Recovery After Significant Backsliding: Emergent Lessons,” Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, April 28, 2025, ",{"children":2006,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":2009},[2007],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2008,"type":756,"version":757},"https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2025/04/democratic-recovery-after-significant-backsliding-emergent-lessons?lang=en",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":2008},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2012,"type":756,"version":757}," First, backsliding leaders differ in the specific institutions and sectors they target. Often, their approach is shaped by underlying features of the domestic context, such as the configuration and rootedness of existing institutions—like whether it is a parliamentary or presidential system—or elements of political tradition and culture. It may also be influenced by contingent features of the context, such as whether the leader has a legislative majority, a well-established party, and particular political skills and inclinations. Second, the pace at which executive aggrandizement proceeds varies. In some cases, leaders move only very gradually, taking years to implement a wide-ranging set of aggrandizing actions, while in others, leaders move much more quickly. Third, the breadth and depth of aggrandizement and its damage differ widely. In some countries, executive aggrandizement has gone so far as to move the country fully away from democracy. In others, it is relatively limited, hurting democratic norms and institutions, but not debilitating the democratic system overall.",{"children":2014,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[2015],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2016,"type":756,"version":757},"Trump’s Three-Level Executive Aggrandizement",{"children":2018,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[2019],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2020,"type":756,"version":757},"During its first seven months, the Trump administration’s policies, statements, and actions comprise a clear attempt at executive aggrandizement. As set out in Figure 1, this effort operates on three interrelated levels—establishing the president as supreme within the executive branch, making the executive branch dominant over other parts of government, and weakening societal constraints on executive Branch","h4",{"children":2065,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[2066,2068,2085],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2067,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration is pursuing a sweeping effort to elevate the president within the executive. Building on theories once considered at the fringe of legal thought, it is asserting a vision for the presidency in which the president reigns supreme over all parts of the executive branch, with even formally independent executive agencies and employees transformed into vehicles for his will. A trend toward greater presidential authority has been growing in U.S. politics, across successive administrations from both parties, for some time. But the current administration is pursuing a much more extreme form of executive concentration of power, one that conforms to what is known as the “unitary executive theory”—which argues that the U.S. Constitution endows the president with total control essentially over the entire executive branch, including positions such as inspectors general and independent agency commissioners.",{"type":1766,"footnote":2069,"version":757},{"root":2070},{"children":2071,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[2072],{"children":2073,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[2074,2076,2077,2079,2084],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2075,"type":756,"version":757},"Cass R.
