Trump’s continuous rhetoric labeling people who disagree with him or who pursue alternative political agendas “evil,” “enemies,” “criminals,” and “lunatics” and his repeated efforts to back some of that rhetoric with tangible punishment has created a climate of political fear unprecedented in modern American history. As one observer recently wrote, “Fear is the universal tool of authoritarians, and it is a clear sign that our democracy is in danger that so many Americans now have reason to fear their government.”",{"type":1766,"footnote":3295,"version":757},{"root":3296},{"children":3297,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3298],{"children":3299,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3300,3302,3303,3304,3309,3311,3312,3314,3319],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3301,"type":756,"version":757},"Frank Kendall, “Fear Comes to America,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1809,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2473,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3305,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3308},[3306],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3307,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/21/opinion/trump-fear-pentagon-harvard.html",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3307},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3310,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Peter Baker, “For Trump, Domestic Adversaries Are Not Just Wrong, They Are ‘Evil,’” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1809,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3313,"type":756,"version":757},", July 16, 2025, ",{"children":3315,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3318},[3316],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3317,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/16/us/politics/trump-political-enemies-evil.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3317},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3321,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1831,"version":757},[3322],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3323,"type":756,"version":757},"The administration is curtailing the basic forms of bottom-up political accountability that are fundamental to a democratic system.",{"children":3325,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3326],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3327,"type":756,"version":757},"Together, these three levels of action by Trump and his administration constitute an integrated, systematic attempt at executive aggrandizement. The administration’s elimination of executive constraints on presidential power and assertions of dominance over the judicial and legislative branches, as well as state governments, are weakening the core institutions and norms of legal and political accountability essential for democratic governance. And by undermining societal opposition and vertical checks on presidential power, the administration is curtailing the basic forms of bottom-up political accountability that are also fundamental to a democratic system.",{"children":3329,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[3330],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3331,"type":756,"version":757},"Comparing to Other Cases",{"children":3333,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3334],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3335,"type":756,"version":757},"How does Trump’s political project compare to the processes of backsliding that have played out in other countries in recent years? A common refrain from political observers is that the Trump administration is following the same pathway set out by leaders in countries like Brazil, Hungary, India, and Türkiye. They worry that the similarities signal that the United States will soon find itself in the same straits as these badly damaged democracies. Certainly, there are important, troubling similarities of both means and goals. Yet there are also differences between the Trump administration’s approach and the executive aggrandizement that has occurred elsewhere. Shedding light on these distinctive elements helps paint a fully nuanced picture of the current state of U.S. democratic backsliding.",{"children":3337,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3338],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3339,"type":756,"version":757},"In pursuit of such illumination, this study compares the United States under Trump to seven recent or ongoing cases of democratic backsliding: Brazil, Ecuador, El Salvador, Hungary, India, Poland, and Türkiye. Figure 2 sets out some basic facts regarding the relevant democratic erosion in these countries. While these do not represent the full range of available cases, they include commonly invoked cases that in their different ways share several important features with the U.S. context. Hungary and Poland are high-income democracies with strong ties to the community of other high-income democratic states. Türkiye, while middle income, experienced notable economic dynamism for most of this century. Brazil, Ecuador, and El Salvador feature presidential systems where elected leaders sought to amass dominant presidential power. In India, executive aggrandizement has taken place within a vast, complex federal structure that oversees a large and diverse society. All of these countries have experienced deepening political polarization, which illiberal leaders have magnified and leveraged in their efforts to expand executive />\u003C/noscript>\u003C/div>",{"children":3379,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3380],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3381,"type":756,"version":757},"In analyzing the United States in relation to these other backsliding cases, this study zeros in on three comparative dimensions of the different processes of executive aggrandizement—focus, rapidity, and severity. Compared to other backsliding cases, it finds that the Trump team has placed a particular emphasis on dominating the executive branch, on delegitimizing horizontal institutions, and on coercing civil society through funding cuts and regulatory pathways. Trump and his team have attacked checks on the executive with unusual speed and aggression. But with regard to severity, U.S. democratic backsliding is not yet as institutionalized or repressive as in some of the other prominent cases. These findings within each of the three dimensions are briefly summarized in Figure 3.",{"format":754,"type":2022,"version":757,"fields":760,"relationTo":2023,"value":3383},{"id":3384,"publishedAt":3385,"status":734,"externalId":3386,"_collection":2023,"locale":696,"translations":3387,"altText":3388,"isDataviz":773,"prefix":2030,"filename":3389,"mimeType":2032,"filesize":3390,"width":2034,"height":3349,"focalX":2036,"focalY":2036,"sizes":3391,"createdAt":3408,"updatedAt":3408,"url":3409},"68a5dce5ce65f958546db064","2025-08-20T14:34:13.932Z",[],{"en":739},"Figure Carrier-figures-03-202508.png",{"children":3411,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[3412],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3413,"type":756,"version":757},"Focus: Trump’s Distinctive Priorities",{"children":3415,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3416],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3417,"type":756,"version":757},"Across different backsliding cases, leaders often prioritize particular focal areas of aggrandizement. In comparison to the other backsliding cases in this study, the Trump administration’s focus on three areas stands out: on intra-executive dominance, on delegitimization and circumvention as strategies to weaken horizontal institutions, and on weaponization of federal funding as a coercive and retributive tool. While other leaders have employed these tactics to varying degrees, the Trump administration is unusual in the extent to which it has prioritized each. This distinctiveness sheds light on the elements of U.S. democracy that have constrained or influenced Trump’s agenda—including the dynamics of its presidential system and the checks on constitutional and institutional change within it.",{"children":3419,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[3420],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3421,"type":756,"version":757},"Intra-executive Dominance",{"children":3423,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3424],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3425,"type":756,"version":757},"In comparison to other backsliding countries, the Trump administration’s approach is uniquely centered on restructuring and dominating the executive branch. Why in the United States and not elsewhere? In the other cases, backsliding leaders faced fewer barriers to gaining consolidated control over the executive from the outset—allowing many aggrandizing leaders to focus fully on targeting legislatures, courts, or civil society. In the United States, Trump operates within a highly (at least until recently) rule-bound executive branch. Internal checks limit presidential overreach from within, and structural constraints make co-opting the legislature or judiciary deeply challenging. As a result, emphasizing intra-executive dominance is a more feasible pathway to early aggrandizement in the United States.",{"children":3427,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3428],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3429,"type":756,"version":757},"From the outset of his tenure, Trump directed his energies toward consolidating control over the branch—purging oversight institutions, politicizing civil service processes, bringing independent agencies under its control, and reducing overall federal bureaucratic capacity. In isolation, the individual tactics that the Trump administration has employed are not unprecedented among backsliding leaders. In cases from Brazil to India to Türkiye, leaders also co-opted oversight agencies and politicized the government workforce. But in such cases, these efforts tended to be a secondary focus within their broader aggrandizement agenda. Their political systems often made it unnecessary or less important to consolidate executive branch control. Instead, the judiciary, legislature, or civil society were the main early focuses as leaders sought to expand their power.",{"children":3431,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3432,3434,3452,3454],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3433,"type":756,"version":757},"This was true in several cases with parliamentary systems, like Hungary and Poland, where horizontal institutions were the first major targets of aggrandizement efforts. In these cases, party dominance within the legislature vested the new leadership with power over their executive apparatuses. In Hungary, Orbán’s Fidesz party won 68 percent of the parliamentary seats in the 2010 elections.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3435,"version":757},{"root":3436},{"children":3437,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3438],{"children":3439,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3440,3442,3443,3445,3450,3451],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3441,"type":756,"version":757},"Miklós Bánkuti, Gábor Halmai, and Kim Lane Scheppele, “Hungary’s Illiberal Turn: Disabling the Constitution,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3444,"type":756,"version":757}," 23, no. 3 (July 2012): 138-46, ",{"children":3446,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3449},[3447],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3448,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/hungarys-illiberal-turn-disabling-the-constitution/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3448},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2221,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2223,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3453,"type":756,"version":757}," As prime minister with a legislative supermajority, Orbán was then empowered to pass constitutional changes that he used to eliminate judicial checks from the Constitutional Court as he pursued his power grab. Similarly, after the Law and Justice (PiS) party came to power in Poland following the 2015 parliamentary elections, the party leveraged its unified executive-legislative control to target horizontal institutions, quickly launching a series of structural changes that undermined the independence of the judiciary.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3455,"version":757},{"root":3456},{"children":3457,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3458],{"children":3459,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3460,3462,3463,3465,3470],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3461,"type":756,"version":757},"Bojan Bugarič and Tom Ginsburg, “The Assault on Postcommunist Courts,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3464,"type":756,"version":757}," 27, no. 3 (July 2016): 69-82, ",{"children":3466,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3469},[3467],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3468,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/the-assault-on-postcommunist-courts/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3468},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3472,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3473,3475,3497],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3474,"type":756,"version":757},"But even among the comparative cases with presidential systems, it is unusual for newly elected leadership to place such emphasis on internal domination of the executive branch. In part, this may be due to a greater presumption in other countries that the executive branch is an extension of presidential will. Consider Rafael Correa’s approach after he assumed the presidency of Ecuador in 2007. Unlike Trump’s ongoing efforts to reshape the executive branch, cutting agencies and firing staff to ensure internal alignment with the administration’s agenda, Correa expanded the executive bureaucracy significantly during his time as president, doubling the number of ministries in his cabinet over a ten-year period.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3476,"version":757},{"root":3477},{"children":3478,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3479,3483],{"children":3480,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3481],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3482,"type":756,"version":757},"Francisco Sánchez and John Polga-Hecimovich, “The Tools of Institutional Change under",{"children":3484,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3485,3487,3489,3491,3496],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3486,"type":756,"version":757},"Post-Neoliberalism: Rafael Correa’s Ecuador,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3488,"type":756,"version":757},"Journal of Latin American Studies",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3490,"type":756,"version":757}," 51, no. 2 (May 2019): 379-408, ",{"children":3492,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3495},[3493],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3494,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-latin-american-studies/article/abs/tools-of-institutional-change-under-postneoliberalism-rafael-correas-ecuador/DD3296262ED709B35355D6368ECC036B",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3494},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3498,"type":756,"version":757}," But even this wasn’t the immediate priority in his aggrandizement agenda—his major focus early on was constraining horizontal democratic institutions. For example, one of his first moves in power was to push for a constituent assembly to bypass Ecuador’s existing legislature, gaining control over the policymaking process and undermining the legislature’s capacity to function as a check on the president.",{"children":3500,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3501,3503,3520,3522],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3502,"type":756,"version":757},"Brazil and India present cases that are in many ways more similar to the U.S. context. When Jair Bolsonaro came to power in Brazil in 2019, he took several measures to politicize the executive branch through the appointment of many military officials and political loyalists to positions within it. But dominating the executive was a lower priority for Bolsonaro than it has been for Trump. Brazil’s system was already characterized by weak executive oversight institutions, and Bolsonaro did not go as far as Trump has already done to fundamentally reshape the executive branch’s internal structure and institutions.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3504,"version":757},{"root":3505},{"children":3506,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3507],{"children":3508,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3509,3511,3512,3514,3519],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3510,"type":756,"version":757},"Umberto Mignozzetti and Matias Spektor, “Brazil: When Political Oligarchies Limit Polarization but Fuel Populism,” in ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1545,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3513,"type":756,"version":757}," eds. Thomas Carothers and Andrew O’Donohue (Brookings Institution Press, 2019): 228-54, ",{"children":3515,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3518},[3516],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3517,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www-jstor-org.ceip.idm.oclc.org/stable/10.7864/j.ctvbd8j2p.12?seq=15",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3517},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3521,"type":756,"version":757}," Similarly, in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) targeted internal watchdog institutions, extensively restructured ministries to align with Modi’s agenda, and consolidated power in the Prime Minister’s Office. But Modi’s legislative majority in India’s parliamentary system gave him alternate political pathways that he has since prioritized in his efforts to target horizontal and civil society dissent.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3523,"version":757},{"root":3524},{"children":3525,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3526],{"children":3527,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3528,3530,3532,3534,3539],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3529,"type":756,"version":757},"Milan Vaishnav, “Legislative Capture in India: Is Democracy Back from the Brink?,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3531,"type":756,"version":757},"The ANNALS of the American Academy of Political and Social Science",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3533,"type":756,"version":757}," 712, no. 1 (2025): 61–76, ",{"children":3535,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3538},[3536],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3537,"type":756,"version":757},"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/00027162241307742",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3537},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3541,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3542],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3543,"type":756,"version":757},"Trump’s approach to the executive branch is more pronounced than those of these other leaders. Amid the constraints and guardrails of the U.S. democratic system, he has relied heavily on executive actions and pathways to enact his agenda. And his concerted effort to dominate the executive branch through extensive restructuring and purging has been a major focus of the early months of his presidency.",{"children":3545,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[3546],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3547,"type":756,"version":757},"Delegitimizing and Circumventing Horizontal Institutions",{"children":3549,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3550],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3551,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration’s approach to weakening horizontal checks is a second distinctive element. Constrained by institutional guardrails that make it difficult to pass constitutional amendments or structurally disempower the courts and legislature, the Trump team has focused on other ways of undercutting the horizontal institutions that stand in its way. Compared to the institutionalized changes that leaders have pursued in other backsliding cases, Trump’s approach has focused much more on normative democratic erosion and the overreach of presidential powers.",{"children":3553,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3554],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3555,"type":756,"version":757},"To undermine the judiciary, for example, the administration has systematically sought—as described above—to discredit the courts rather than pursue structural changes. The administration has not made the U.S. Supreme Court a direct target—given that it leans strongly conservative and is a well-established institution within American democracy, it is a low-reward, high-cost institution for Trump to attack. But the administration has challenged the legitimacy of judicial constraints on the executive broadly, and ignored, attacked, and avoided full or timely implementation of judicial rulings against it.",{"children":3557,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3558],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3559,"type":756,"version":757},"Trump’s approach is markedly different than the constitutional amendments or legislative measures that leaders in other countries have used to structurally weaken the courts. For example, the PiS enacted deep institutional changes to the Polish judiciary. There, while the government also heavily criticized the judiciary, it paired these attacks with legal changes that brought the Polish court system under party control. PiS legislators vested the administration with the authority to determine appointments to the Polish National Council of the Judiciary and lowered the retirement age for Supreme Court justices to enable PiS to pack the court with party loyalists. They passed legal measures that reduced the powers of the Constitutional Tribunal and changed the regulations governing the Supreme Court to further diminish its independence.",{"children":3561,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3562,3564,3585],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3563,"type":756,"version":757},"In El Salvador, too, when President Nayib Bukele’s party won a legislative supermajority in 2021, he led a series of legal changes to bring the judiciary under executive control. His party-held legislature removed every justice from the country’s constitutional court, installing its own replacements. It passed laws that enabled the administration to remove judges above a certain age and that gave Bukele greater control over the terms of judges.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3565,"version":757},{"root":3566},{"children":3567,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3568],{"children":3569,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3570,3572,3577,3579,3584],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3571,"type":756,"version":757},"Human Rights Watch, “El Salvador: New Laws Threaten Judicial Independence,” September 2, 2021, ",{"children":3573,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3576},[3574],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3575,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.hrw.org/news/2021/09/02/el-salvador-new-laws-threaten-judicial-independence",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3575},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3578,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Sean McGinley, “Stealth Authoritarian Tactics in El Salvador,” Democratic Erosion Consortium, May 8, 2024, ",{"children":3580,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3583},[3581],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3582,"type":756,"version":757},"https://democratic-erosion.org/2024/05/08/stealth-authoritarian-tactics-in-el-salvador/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3582},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3586,"type":756,"version":757}," Institutionalized control over the judiciary has subsequently aided Bukele’s effort to expand his executive control, for example through a Constitutional Court decision allowing Bukele to circumvent term limits. Like in Poland and El Salvador, structural changes to the judiciary also took place in Ecuador, Hungary, and Türkiye.",{"children":3588,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3589,3591,3605,3607],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3590,"type":756,"version":757},"While most of the comparative cases involved some degree of institutionalized attacks on the independence and strength of judiciaries, some other backsliding leaders have, like Trump, also tried to delegitimize the judiciary. Most notably, Bolsonaro’s attacks on Brazil’s Supreme Court were strikingly similar to the rhetoric currently coming out of the Trump administration. Amid investigations into Bolsonaro’s illiberal actions, Bolsonaro repeatedly claimed the court was overreaching, threatened to impeach justices, and even suggested that he would not adhere to unfavorable court decisions.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3592,"version":757},{"root":3593},{"children":3594,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3595],{"children":3596,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3597,3599,3604],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3598,"type":756,"version":757},"Human ",{"children":3600,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3603},[3601],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3602,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.hrw.org/news/2021/09/15/brazil-bolsonaro-threatens-democratic-rule",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3602},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3606,"type":756,"version":757}," In India, while Modi’s government has not succeeded in exerting formal control over the judiciary, it has leveraged regulatory processes to undermine oppositional judges and boost loyalists, creating a culture of judicial self-abrogation.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3608,"version":757},{"root":3609},{"children":3610,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3611],{"children":3612,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3613,3615,3616,3618,3623],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3614,"type":756,"version":757},"Madhav ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3617,"type":756,"version":757}," 32, no. 1 (January ",{"children":3619,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3622},[3620],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3621,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/the-three-faces-of-the-indian-state/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3621},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3625,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3626,3628,3646],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3627,"type":756,"version":757},"Judicial delegitimization also can precede efforts at institutional change. In Türkiye, for example, Erdoğan clashed with the judiciary relatively early on in his tenure, highlighting issues that were broadly popular with Turkish society to erode public support for the courts. But he then capitalized upon this discontent to justify his institutional weakening of the judicial system and expansion of executive power through constitutional changes in 2010.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3629,"version":757},{"root":3630},{"children":3631,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3632],{"children":3633,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3634,3636,3638,3640,3645],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3635,"type":756,"version":757},"Andrew Atlantic",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3639,"type":756,"version":757},", May 14, 2025, ",{"children":3641,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3644},[3642],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3643,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2025/05/trump-court-autocrat-popular-issues/682797/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3643},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3647,"type":756,"version":757}," Though there are clear early parallels between Erdoğan’s and Trump’s tactics, it remains to be seen if the Trump administration’s emphasis on judicial delegitimization will evolve into similar attempts to structurally change the judiciary, or if—like in Brazil—Trump’s erosion of judicial authority will remain mostly in the form of vituperations and disobedience.",{"children":3649,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3650],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3651,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration’s approach to Congress—often subverting or circumventing it rather than co-opting or enlisting it—is also distinctive compared to other executive aggrandizement cases. In other cases, the executive and legislature have worked in tandem to weaken democratic checks and expand executive power through legislative means. In parliamentary systems like Hungary and Poland, where executives are selected by and beholden to their legislative majority, the legislature is a natural pathway for the leadership’s backsliding agenda. In Poland, for example, the PiS-led parliament and former president Andrzej Duda systematically eroded the independence of the judiciary and civil society through extensive legislative changes.",{"children":3653,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3654,3656,3680,3682],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3655,"type":756,"version":757},"Even compared to other presidential cases, the Trump administration has still placed a greater emphasis than other leaders on subverting rather than co-opting the legislature. While other presidents also employ executive powers to enact their aggrandizement projects, such leaders often do so in lockstep with their legislatures. For instance, in El Salvador, even though Bukele has deployed a state of emergency to consolidate control over much of civil society, he has also made extensive use of legislative pathways in his efforts—such as when he leveraged his majority in the Legislative Assembly to enact changes that weakened the judiciary at the outset of his backsliding drive, or in August 2025, when the legislature approved amendments to the constitution that abolished presidential term limits.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3657,"version":757},{"root":3658},{"children":3659,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3660],{"children":3661,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3662,3664,3669,3671,3672,3674,3679],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3663,"type":756,"version":757},"Kayleigh Slifko, “El Salvador’s Security Crackdown: A Path to Authoritarianism?,” Democratic Erosion Consortium, November 4, 2024, ",{"children":3665,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3668},[3666],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3667,"type":756,"version":757},"https://democratic-erosion.org/2024/11/04/el-salvadors-security-crackdown-a-path-to-authoritarianism/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3667},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3670,"type":756,"version":757},"; Conaghan, “Delegative Democracy Revisited: Ecuador Under Correa,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3692,"type":756,"version":757}," 27, no. 3 (July 2016): 109-118, ",{"children":3694,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3697},[3695],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3696,"type":756,"version":757},"https://muse.jhu.edu/article/623612/pdf?casa_token=zmy-daiImCsAAAAA:MCCXziZAHG_xS7_3811PBhXsEODi3fp1e_mTFFdZBFIQbuDiehBwAYLRanz072z1zTReb6W5OsA",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3696},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3700,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1831,"version":757},[3701],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3702,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration has relied predominantly on executive orders, states of emergency, funding threats and cut-offs, and rhetorical tactics to achieve its executive aggrandizement ends, with little energy spent on legislative pathways.",{"children":3704,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3705],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3706,"type":756,"version":757},"By contrast, the Trump administration has relied predominantly on executive orders, states of emergency, funding threats and cut-offs, and rhetorical tactics to achieve its executive aggrandizement ends, with little energy spent on legislative pathways. In part, this reflects Trump’s narrow legislative majority and the constraints of the U.S. system. The slim Republican majorities in the House and Senate do not give Trump and his allies the unfettered capacity to enact nationwide changes at speed and scale. A complex, bicameral legislative process with a filibuster makes legislation a challenging avenue for change, while state governance and the federal system provide another check on legislative influence. In many ways, Congress is simply a less effective avenue than others through which Trump can carry out his aggrandizement agenda. And using executive orders and emergency powers to enact policy serves Trump’s aggrandizement goals. Constitutional change is notoriously difficult in the United States, making the constitutional restructuring of legislatures that took place in cases like Ecuador, Hungary, and Türkiye practically unfeasible for Trump. But by circumventing legislative authority repeatedly, Trump’s administration continues to set new precedents for presidential authority that shift the normative baseline of control over policy issues in Trump’s favor.",{"children":3708,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[3709],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3710,"type":756,"version":757},"Leveraging Federal Funding to Coerce Civil Society",{"children":3712,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3713],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3714,"type":756,"version":757},"A third distinctive focal point of Trump’s aggrandizement agenda is his use of federal funding to intimidate and constrain U.S. civil society. In itself, this is not unusual among backsliding leaders. Cutting off resources for independent societal organizations is a common tactic within the executive aggrandizement model. But two features of the U.S. context stand out. First, few governments oversee funding channels as expansive as those that exist within the United States, and few countries contain civil society ecosystems as large and institutionally embedded. This makes federal funding a particularly impactful coercive tool for the Trump administration. Second, unlike leaders in most of the comparative backsliding cases, Trump has not yet imposed sweeping legal repression of civil society. Legal and normative guardrails make this a challenging pathway in the United States. But it is notable that the administration has made such aggressive use of the funding and regulatory tools that are available to it to weaken oppositional civil society and punish organizations that refuse to comply with its demands.",{"children":3716,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3717,3719,3733],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3718,"type":756,"version":757},"Other backsliding leaders have also focused on funding mechanisms as levers to exert control over civil society groups. ",{"type":1766,"footnote":3822,"version":757},{"root":3823},{"children":3824,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3825],{"children":3826,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3827,3829,3834],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3828,"type":756,"version":757},"Maria Meco, “Hungary’s Assault on Academic Freedom,” Democratic Erosion Consortium, May 2, 2024, ",{"children":3830,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3833},[3831],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3832,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.democratic-erosion.com/2024/05/02/hungarys-assault-on-academic-freedom/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3832},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3836,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3837],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3838,"type":756,"version":757},"It might seem comforting that the administration’s assault on civil society has prioritized tactics like financial coercion rather than more deep, repressive institutionalization. But is the pace of Trump’s executive aggrandizement exceptional?",{"children":3881,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3882],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3883,"type":756,"version":757},"The conclusions that emerge from a comparative evaluation are concerning. Relative to other backsliding cases, the Trump team has acted with uncommon early momentum in its efforts to consolidate power. It has sustained its efforts simultaneously across multiple domains of American democracy, consolidating the process that many overreaching executives only achieve incrementally over a longer time. And the rapidity of Trump’s erosion of democratic norms has also been notable, even in comparison to other aggressive backsliding cases.",{"children":3885,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[3886],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3887,"type":756,"version":757},"Early Momentum and Speed of Backsliding",{"children":3889,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3890],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3891,"type":756,"version":757},"The early and sustained speed of Trump’s executive aggrandizement sets the United States apart from other backsliding cases. Trump arrived at the presidency with immense power to enact his agenda. His party controls both houses of Congress. The Supreme Court is friendly to his administration. He fields a large, loyal base of politicians and citizens. Yet even with the typical levers of presidential power at his disposal, he chose not to move incrementally or play by the rules of the game before he began to upend democratic norms.",{"children":3893,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3894],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3895,"type":756,"version":757},"In comparison, backsliding leaders are often elected with a purported commitment to uphold or even strengthen their country’s democracy. They have been granted access to the levers of power through their electoral victory, and there is little pressing need to dismantle the system that—for the moment—serves their interests. While some leaders may take early steps to assert control over opposition-held institutions, the overreach process tends to be incremental.",{"children":3897,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3898,3900,3917,3919],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3899,"type":756,"version":757},"Take Türkiye, for example, where Erdoğan’s consolidation of power came several years into his tenure as leader of the country. When the AKP and Erdoğan campaigned before first coming to power in 2002, they presented themselves as a democratic option for Turkish voters and promised to advance the rule of law, civil society freedoms, and Türkiye’s accession to the European Union. Indeed, in the initial years of Erdoğan’s tenure as prime minister, he was widely lauded internationally for his democratic leadership and liberal reforms—a marked contrast with the criticism the Trump administration attracted for its early disregard for democratic norms.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3901,"version":757},{"root":3902},{"children":3903,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3904],{"children":3905,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3906,3908,3909,3911,3916],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3907,"type":756,"version":757},"Thomas ",{"children":3912,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3915},[3913],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3914,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/misunderstanding-democratic-backsliding/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3914},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3918,"type":756,"version":757}," later.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3920,"version":757},{"root":3921},{"children":3922,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3923],{"children":3924,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3925,3927,3928,3930,3935],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3926,"type":756,"version":757},"Murat Somer, “A Long Battle: Turkey’s Backsliding and Resistance Through Trench Warfare,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3531,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3929,"type":756,"version":757}," 712, no. 1 (March 2025): 77–92, ",{"children":3931,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3934},[3932],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3933,"type":756,"version":757},"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/00027162251318839",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3933},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3937,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3938,3940],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3939,"type":756,"version":757},"India, too, exemplifies the gradualness that usually characterizes the common democratic backsliding model. Modi did not immediately dismantle democratic institutions at the outset of his tenure as prime minister in 2014. Rather, over the subsequent decade he has utilized his strong parliamentary backing and repressive techniques step by step to centralize power and create a culture of fear that prevents meaningful civil society mobilization or political opposition. His government only incrementally employed tools such as sedition laws, retribution against political opponents, and restrictions on media and civil society. These tactics are comparable to the United States, where Trump’s early assault on U.S. law firms through targeted executive orders quickly led other law firms to acquiesce to the administration’s demands. But while this unfolded over mere weeks in the United States, it was the accumulative use of such measures over years in India that has suppressed meaningful pushback by civil society and judicial bodies.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3941,"version":757},{"root":3942},{"children":3943,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3944],{"children":3945,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3946,3948,3949,3951,3956],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3947,"type":756,"version":757},"Milan Vaishnav, “The Challenge of India’s Democratic Backsliding,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":14,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3950,"type":756,"version":757}," 62 (2021), ",{"children":3952,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3955},[3953],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3954,"type":756,"version":757},"https://democracyjournal.org/magazine/62-special-issue/the-challenge-of-indias-democratic-backsliding/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3954},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":3958,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3959,3961,3978],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3960,"type":756,"version":757},"Not all cases of backsliding unfold slowly. In some cases, leaders with backsliding intent enact an immediate, rapid agenda to overcome a position of political weakness. In Ecuador, for example, while Correa won the 2007 presidential election, he faced strong opposition in the legislature that posed a meaningful constraint on his political capacity. He quickly called for a constituent assembly, which he filled with political allies. With Correa’s backing, the constituent assembly suspended Congress and vested itself with the country’s policymaking powers, co-opting the legislature completely.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3962,"version":757},{"root":3963},{"children":3964,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3965],{"children":3966,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3967,3969,3970,3972,3977],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3968,"type":756,"version":757},"Paolo Moncagatta and Mateo Pazmiño, “A Tale of a Failed Recovery: Ecuador’s Democratic Stagnation,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3531,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3971,"type":756,"version":757}," 712, no. 1 (March 2025): 137–51, ",{"children":3973,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":3976},[3974],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3975,"type":756,"version":757},"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/00027162241312518",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3975},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3979,"type":756,"version":757}," But after Correa’s initial assault on the legislature, his subsequent overreach strategy did not sustain this initial momentum. His approach over the ensuing decade was certainly aggressive, but it proceeded more slowly and incrementally. By contrast, Trump faces no major legislative pushback to his agenda that would necessitate an early power grab of this type. He is operating from a position of power and seeking to amass even more power.",{"children":3981,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3982,3984,4003,4005],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3983,"type":756,"version":757},"There are a few cases of executive-led democratic backsliding that more closely resemble the rapid approach of the Trump administration’s first few months. Poland’s democratic erosion, for example, was also characterized by a quick assault on democratic checks on the executive right out of the gate. PiS assumed power in October 2015 with a slim parliamentary majority. Almost immediately, the newly formed government moved to weaken the judiciary, media, and civil service. Within its first year, PiS undermined the Constitutional Tribunal by politicizing its appointments and limiting its oversight capacities, and—much like the Trump administration’s ongoing disobedience of judicial mandates—began rejecting tribunal rulings outright.",{"type":1766,"footnote":3985,"version":757},{"root":3986},{"children":3987,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[3988],{"children":3989,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[3990,3992,3994,3996,4001,4002],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3991,"type":756,"version":757},"John Macy and Allyson K. Duncan, “The Collapse of Judicial Independence in Poland: A Cautionary Tale,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3993,"type":756,"version":757},"Judicature International",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3995,"type":756,"version":757}," 104, no. 3 (2020-21), ",{"children":3997,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4000},[3998],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":3999,"type":756,"version":757},"https://judicature.duke.edu/articles/the-collapse-of-judicial-independence-in-poland-a-cautionary-tale/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":3999},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2221,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2223,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4004,"type":756,"version":757}," It expanded government control over Poland’s public media services and used this power to purge critical journalists. And it politicized the country’s civil service through changes to the Civil Service Act—another move that parallels the Trump administration’s ongoing politicization of the federal bureaucracy.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4006,"version":757},{"root":4007},{"children":4008,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4009],{"children":4010,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4011,4013,4015,4017,4022],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4012,"type":756,"version":757},"Stanisław Mazur, Michał Możdżeń, and Marek Oramus, “The Instrumental and Ideological Politicisation of Senior Positions in Poland’s Civil Service and its Selected Consequences,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4014,"type":756,"version":757},"NISPAcee Journal of Public Administration and Policy",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4016,"type":756,"version":757}," 11, no. 1 (June 2018): 63-89, ",{"children":4018,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4021},[4019],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4020,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/326480637_The_Instrumental_and_Ideological_Politicisation_of_Senior_Positions_in_Poland's_Civil_Service_and_its_Selected_Consequences",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4020},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":4024,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4025,4027,4046],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4026,"type":756,"version":757},"Hungary, too, saw a rapid expansion of executive power after Orbán and the Fidesz party regained power in May 2010. By the end of that year, the Fidesz government had packed key institutions and agencies with party loyalists, passed constitutional changes to weaken the oversight capacity of Hungary’s Constitutional Court, reduced the size of the legislature, eliminated funding for civil society groups, and passed new media restrictions.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4028,"version":757},{"root":4029},{"children":4030,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4031],{"children":4032,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4033,4034,4036,4038,4040,4045],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2223,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4035,"type":756,"version":757},"Balázs Áron Kovács and Flóra Hevesi, “Hungary” in ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4037,"type":756,"version":757},"Nations in Transit 2011: Democratization from Central Europe to Eurasia",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4039,"type":756,"version":757}," (Freedom House, 2011), ",{"children":4041,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4044},[4042],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4043,"type":756,"version":757},"https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/inline_images/NIT-2011-Hungary.pdf",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4043},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4047,"type":756,"version":757}," Much like the Trump administration, Orbán’s team asserted dominance over various levels of Hungary’s democratic system—from the co-opting of independent agencies to the weakening of civil society organizations. And, also like the Trump team’s approach, the Fidesz government enacted these changes with rapidity after assuming power.",{"children":4049,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1831,"version":757},[4050],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4051,"type":756,"version":757},"Even in comparison to similar cases like Poland and Hungary, Trump’s actions over the past months reflect an unusually condensed timeline and rapid upending of democratic norms.",{"children":4053,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4054,4056,4064],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4055,"type":756,"version":757},"But even in comparison to similar cases like Poland and Hungary, Trump’s actions over the past months reflect an unusually condensed timeline and rapid upending of democratic norms. While the PiS and Fidesz governments each oversaw significant democratic erosion in their first year, the Trump administration compressed into its first weeks of overt defiance and institutional disruption of democratic systems what took months to unfold in these other cases. For example, steps comparable to the series of measures that Trump took in his early days to consolidate control over the executive workforce took form over a year-long period in Hungary.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4057,"version":757},{"root":4058},{"children":4059,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4060],{"children":4061,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4062],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4063,"type":756,"version":757},"Áron Kovács and Hevesi, “Hungary.”",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4065,"type":756,"version":757}," Trump’s team began to defy the judicial system in the first weeks of his presidency. In Poland, by contrast, while the PiS government moved swiftly to reshape the Polish judiciary, it was not until months into its tenure that the party began to explicitly deny the legitimacy of the courts.",{"children":4067,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[4068],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4069,"type":756,"version":757},"Simultaneous, Multilevel Approach",{"children":4071,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4072,4074,4082,4084],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4073,"type":756,"version":757},"In addition to the speed of the administration’s efforts, it is also notable that it has maintained this rapid approach simultaneously across the different domains of U.S. democracy. In other backsliding cases, leaders commonly targeted their country’s democratic checks in a piece-by-piece fashion. In Türkiye, it was through incremental changes over many years that Erdoğan weakened Turkish democratic institutions in changes like the 2010 constitutional referendum to increase the executive’s control over the courts and another referendum in 2017 to weaken the legislature and establish a system with an extremely powerful presidency.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4075,"version":757},{"root":4076},{"children":4077,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4078],{"children":4079,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4080],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4081,"type":756,"version":757},"Somer, “A Long Battle: Turkey’s Backsliding and Resistance Through Trench Warfare.",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4083,"type":756,"version":757}," Correa’s approach was also less unified. Over a decade, he periodically targeted democratic institutions. He first created a new executive-aggrandizing constitution. Subsequently, his government pushed through constitutional changes that weakened the judiciary and the press. It was only later that Correa implemented stringent restrictions on civil society organizations and gatherings.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4085,"version":757},{"root":4086},{"children":4087,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4088],{"children":4089,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4090],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4091,"type":756,"version":757},"Moncagatta and Pazmiño, “A Tale of a Failed Recovery: Ecuador’s Democratic Stagnation.”",{"children":4093,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4094],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4095,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump team has not employed this sort of institution-by-institution approach. Rather, it has aggressively pursued all three levels of its aggrandizement agenda simultaneously. During his first week as president in January 2025, Trump issued a host of executive orders, statements, and restructurings that targeted the executive branch, horizontal institutions, and civil society. And in subsequent months, the three-level effort has not let up. His team has continued to exert dominance by stacking the different elements of his aggrandizement agenda into a compressed and simultaneous push that makes identifying and responding to its illiberal elements especially challenging for pro-democracy actors.",{"children":4097,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[4098],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4099,"type":756,"version":757},"Severity: Some Limits—For Now",{"children":4101,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4102],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4103,"type":756,"version":757},"While the Trump administration’s pursuit of executive dominance has been particularly fast, the degree of democratic erosion in the United States is not yet as severe as that of most of its backsliding peers. Most of America’s democratic institutions and processes remain intact, protected by the Constitution and other U.S. laws. The administration’s policies and procedures have undermined democratic norms, but its aggrandizement agenda is not, at least yet, as deeply institutionalized as in the majority of the comparative cases studied. And U.S. democracy has not devolved to the levels of political violence and repression that characterize some of the backsliding countries in this study and beyond. Yet while the United States might not have slid as far toward autocracy as many democracies before it, the weakening of what were previously viewed as unusually strong democratic guardrails is nevertheless unprecedented in modern U.S. history and deeply troubling.",{"children":4105,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[4106],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4107,"type":756,"version":757},"Non-institutionalized Backsliding",{"children":4109,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4110,4112,4126],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4111,"type":756,"version":757},"Democratic erosion has thus far been less institutionalized in the United States than in most of the comparative backsliding cases. For example, to weaken horizontal checks on the executive, Trump’s primary tactic has been the erosion of democratic norms—that is, the informal, unwritten rules of democracy—rather than structural, legal change. As discussed above, the administration has prioritized efforts to delegitimize the judiciary. This approach could ultimately pave the path for the structural weakening of the judiciary, as the Turkish case exemplifies. And the Supreme Court’s ruling in June limiting the ability of federal courts to issue universal injunctions is for some observers a worrying development in this direction.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4113,"version":757},{"root":4114},{"children":4115,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4116],{"children":4117,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4118,4120,4125],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4119,"type":756,"version":757},"Sam Hananel, “Supreme Court Limit on Injunctions Upends the Rule of Law,” Center for American Progress, June 27, 2025, ",{"children":4121,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4124},[4122],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4123,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.americanprogress.org/press/statement-supreme-court-limit-on-injunctions-upends-the-rule-of-law/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4123},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4127,"type":756,"version":757}," But the U.S. case still does not entail the types of structural judicial changes that eliminated Polish judicial independence or weakened the authority of Ecuador’s courts.",{"children":4129,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1831,"version":757},[4130],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4131,"type":756,"version":757},"To weaken horizontal checks on the executive, Trump’s primary tactic has been the erosion of democratic norms—that is, the informal, unwritten rules of democracy—rather than structural, legal change.",{"children":4133,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4134],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4135,"type":756,"version":757},"Brazilian judicial delegitimization under Bolsonaro is a more similar case of normative rather than institutional democratic decline with regard to the judiciary. As outlined above, Bolsonaro leaned heavily into verbal assaults on Brazilian courts and never translated this into structural changes to Brazil’s judiciary. Throughout his tenure, the judicial system remained an independent and important democratic check on his illiberal agenda. Trump’s attacks on U.S. courts have already gone further than Bolsonaro’s—including the outright defiance of court mandates. But like Bolsonaro, Trump and his administration have not sought constitutional change or legislative avenues to override the authority or independence of America’s judiciary.",{"children":4137,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4138],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4139,"type":756,"version":757},"Similarly, though Trump has bypassed Congress through various evasive maneuvers, he has not rewritten the rules of legislative procedure or implemented structural changes to constrain the legislature. This sets the United States apart from the other presidential cases in this study, like Ecuador, in which illiberal leadership fundamentally altered legislative institutions, functionally eliminating their capacities to constrain the executive. While a Republican-led Congress might not present meaningful checks on Trump’s executive actions out of party loyalty, the lack of institutional weakening may provide avenues for democratic pushback or recovery down the road.",{"children":4141,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1831,"version":757},[4142],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4143,"type":756,"version":757},"While a Republican-led Congress might not present meaningful checks on Trump’s executive actions out of party loyalty, the lack of institutional weakening may provide avenues for democratic pushback or recovery down the road.",{"children":4145,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4146,4148,4166,4168,4186],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4147,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration’s efforts to weaken societal constraints on the executive have also been characterized by a lower degree of institutionalization compared to other executive aggrandizement cases. For example, a common tactic among backsliding leaders is their use of legal restrictions on civil society organizations or individuals to dampen societal pushback or constraints. In Ecuador, Correa’s allies passed laws in 2013 that mandated that organizations report on their activities to the government, banned “partisan activities,” and shut down groups that participated in advocacy against government policies.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4149,"version":757},{"root":4150},{"children":4151,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4152],{"children":4153,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4154,4156,4157,4159,4164,4165],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4155,"type":756,"version":757},"Catherine M. Conaghan, “Ecuador: Correa’s Plebiscitary Presidency,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1944,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4158,"type":756,"version":757}," 19, no. 2 (April 2008): 46-60, ",{"children":4160,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4163},[4161],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4162,"type":756,"version":757},"https://ceip.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/ecuador-correas-plebiscitary-presidency/docview/195562055/se-2?accountid=40995",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4162},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2221,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":2223,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4167,"type":756,"version":757}," In India, Modi’s government has cracked down on societal dissent, relying on sedition laws and restrictions on free speech to police its public.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4169,"version":757},{"root":4170},{"children":4171,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4172],{"children":4173,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4174,4176,4178,4180,4185],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4175,"type":756,"version":757},"Milan Vaishnav, “Backsliding In India? The Weakening of Referee Institutions” in ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4177,"type":756,"version":757},"Global Challenges to Democracy",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4179,"type":756,"version":757},", eds. Valerie J. Bunce, Thomas B. Pepinsky, Rachel Beatty Riedl, and Kenneth M. Roberts (Cambridge University Press, 2025), ",{"children":4181,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4184},[4182],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4183,"type":756,"version":757},"https://milanvaishnav.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/backsliding_in_india-final.pdf",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4183},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4187,"type":756,"version":757}," This has not yet been the case in the United States. The Trump administration’s targeting of individuals, law firms, and universities has undeniably had a chilling effect on public institutions and civil society groups—and there are worries that legal restrictions might still emerge. But as of now, U.S. civil society remains free of broad restrictions and vertical accountability remains a viable check on executive power.",{"children":4189,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4190,4192,4200,4202,4223],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4191,"type":756,"version":757},"The Trump administration’s tactics to repress critical media reflect a similar overall pattern as found in other backsliding regimes but are not yet as institutionalized as in other cases. Trump and his team have targeted certain news sites with investigations and lawsuits, restricted press groups from accessing government events, and repeatedly attacked or criticized journalists and news organizations. Several of these tactics do echo cases like El Salvador, Hungary, Poland, and Türkiye, where backsliding leadership frequently delegitimized the press and used strategic lawsuits to weaken independent outlets. But in comparison to such cases, the Trump administration has not gone as far in its efforts to legally constrain or co-opt independent media. Under the Fidesz administration in Hungary, for example, the government acquired media companies and compiled them under the Central European Press and Media Foundation in 2018, ensuring that pro-government coverage dominated the country’s media ecosystem. In Poland, too, gaining control over the country’s largest public media companies gave PiS the ability to skew coverage of the administration and was a difficult institutional change for the subsequent administration to untangle.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4193,"version":757},{"root":4194},{"children":4195,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4196],{"children":4197,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4198],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4199,"type":756,"version":757},"Carothers and Carrier, \"Democratic Recovery After Significant Backsliding.\"",{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4201,"type":756,"version":757}," In Türkiye, the Erdoğan government used legal punishment to silence critical press and pushed for the sale of media outlets to pro-government companies.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4203,"version":757},{"root":4204},{"children":4205,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4206],{"children":4207,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4208,4210,4215,4217,4222],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4209,"type":756,"version":757},"Max Hoffman and Michael Werz, “Freedom of the Press and Expression in Turkey,” Center for American Progress, May 14, 2013, ",{"children":4211,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4214},[4212],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4213,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.americanprogress.org/article/freedom-of-the-press-and-expression-in-turkey/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4213},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4216,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Daren Butler and Ece Toksabay, “Sale of Dogan Set to Tighten Erdogan’s Grip Over Turkish Media,” Reuters, March 22, 2018, ",{"children":4218,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4221},[4219],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4220,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-dogan-holding-m-a-demiroren/sale-of-dogan-set-to-tighten-erdogans-grip-over-turkish-media-idUSKBN1GY0EL/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4220},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4224,"type":756,"version":757}," Whether the Trump administration will succeed in codifying such restrictions remains to be seen, but U.S. media is less structurally constrained or imperiled than in other important cases.",{"children":4226,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4227],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4228,"type":756,"version":757},"The emphasis that the Trump administration has placed on restructuring the executive branch is an exception to this overall low level of institutionalization. However, even in this domain, the Trump administration has not formalized its changes through legislative or constitutional changes. Instead, his team has primarily employed a combination of personnel changes and procedural shifts. To target federal agencies focused on oversight and accountability, for example, Trump fired leadership at the Office of Special Counsel, the Office of Government Ethics, the National Labor Relations Board, the Federal Trade Commission, and others. And he has used executive orders to mandate greater White House oversight of independent executive agencies, to change procedures to make it easier to fire civil servants, and to politicize the federal hiring process.",{"children":4230,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4231,4233,4255,4257],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4232,"type":756,"version":757},"In the common backsliding model, this subjugation of executive agencies and workers is often enshrined in more formal ways. Türkiye is an extreme example, where Erdoğan’s AKP party successfully amended the Constitution in 2017 to formalize presidential dominance over the executive branch. These changes eliminated the prime minister role, establishing the Turkish president as head of both the state and executive, expanding his power to unilaterally select his officials without parliamentary oversight, and granting him the authority to shape the executive branch and create new ministries.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4234,"version":757},{"root":4235},{"children":4236,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4237,4241],{"children":4238,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4239],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4240,"type":756,"version":757},"Berk Esen and Şebnem Gümüşçü, “A Small Yes for Presidentialism: The Turkish Constitutional",{"children":4242,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4243,4245,4247,4249,4254],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4244,"type":756,"version":757},"Referendum ",{"children":4250,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4253},[4251],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4252,"type":756,"version":757},"https://research-ebsco-com.ceip.idm.oclc.org/c/43anfb/viewer/pdf/sdrfycn63n?route=details",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4252},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4256,"type":756,"version":757}," In countries like Hungary and Poland, too, efforts to cement the new leadership’s control over civil servants and the state administration were enacted through
