Cayton and Bryn Rosenfeld, “Democratic Backsliding and the Politicization of Public Employment” in ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4177,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4179,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":4268,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4271},[4269],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4270,"type":756,"version":757},"https://static1.squarespace.com/static/65fb2f3cef43ff68395ebfbc/t/681477212bd32717e039ad70/1746171682454/democratic_backsliding_and_the_politicization_of_public_employment.pdf",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4270},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":4274,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4275],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4276,"type":756,"version":757},"Across the three levels of the Trump administration’s aggrandizement project, democratic erosion has not become as deeply rooted as it has in many other backsliding cases. In the years to come, it remains to be seen whether the administration will seek to and succeed in more firmly institutionalizing its executive aggrandizement, or if U.S. checks and balances will prevent it from doing so.",{"children":4278,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":2063},[4279],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4280,"type":756,"version":757},"Limited Repressive Measures",{"children":4282,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4283,4285,4299],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4284,"type":756,"version":757},"The degree of repression inflicted on political and civic opponents by the Trump administration is lower than what occurred in most of the comparison cases. On one hand, through their retributive actions and rhetoric, and their constant use of extreme political language, Trump and his team have contributed significantly to an increasingly retributive U.S. political culture. Trump has, for example, persistently attacked judges and other elected officials, and research has found that such comments have coincided with “escalating violent posts on social media,” where threats of violence and calls for impeachment against judges have risen “327 percent between May 2024 and March 2025.”",{"type":1766,"footnote":4286,"version":757},{"root":4287},{"children":4288,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4289],{"children":4290,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4291,4293,4298],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4292,"type":756,"version":757},"Global But the administration has not widely used coercive force or criminalization to sideline political opposition, silence critical media, or dampen societal In El Salvador, Bukele leveraged his emergency powers to deploy the military and curtail civil liberties in 2022. His forces cracked down on civilians, resulting in widespread imprisonment and ",{"children":4350,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4353},[4351],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4352,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2024/12/el-salvador-mil-dias-regimen-excepcion-modelo-seguridad-a-costa-derechos-humanos/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4352},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4356,"type":756,"version":757}," ",{"children":4366,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4369},[4367],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4368,"type":756,"version":757},"https://democratic-erosion.org/2024/11/04/the-militarization-of-government-and-policing-in-brazil-a-case-study-of-democratic-backsliding-under-jair-bolsonaro/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4368},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4372,"type":756,"version":757}," ",{"children":4382,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4385},[4383],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4384,"type":756,"version":757},"https://democratic-erosion.org/2021/03/25/myanmars-fight-for-democracy-wont-end-easily/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4384},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4387,"type":756,"version":757},"; and Madison Smrz, “Democratic Breakdown Turns Violent in Venezuela,” Democratic Erosion Consortium, October 14, 2020, ",{"children":4396,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4399},[4397],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4398,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.democratic-erosion.com/2020/10/14/democratic-breakdown-turns-violent-in-venezuela/",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4398},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"children":4402,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4403,4405,4422],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4404,"type":756,"version":757},"Thus far, the U.S. case more closely resembles countries where elite-led polarization has contributed to increasingly violent political cultures more than it has produced overt government repression—like India, where Modi’s Hindu nationalist agenda has fomented deepening sectarian polarization and vigilantism within Indian society.",{"type":1766,"footnote":4406,"version":757},{"root":4407},{"children":4408,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":761,"version":757},[4409],{"children":4410,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4411,4413,4414,4416,4421],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4412,"type":756,"version":757},"Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar, “‘Cow Vigilantes’ Have India’s Muslims on Edge,” ",{"detail":752,"format":1544,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1809,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4415,"type":756,"version":757},", September 7, 2024, ",{"children":4417,"direction":760,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1782,"version":1544,"fields":4420},[4418],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4419,"type":756,"version":757},"https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/07/world/asia/india-religious-violence-muslims-modi.html",{"doc":760,"linkType":1784,"newTab":773,"url":4419},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":1793,"type":756,"version":757},{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4423,"type":756,"version":757}," Of course, it is still early into the administration, and other backsliding leaders often only initiated more violent tactics later into their backsliding drives. Most worrisome in this regard have been the administration’s extremely harsh tactics in its deportation policies, and the almost reflexive militarization of its response to protests on that issue.",{"children":4425,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[4426],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4427,"type":756,"version":757},"Conclusions",{"children":4429,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4430],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4431,"type":756,"version":757},"President Donald Trump’s effort to consolidate executive dominance over all parts of the U.S. political system parallels the campaigns of executive aggrandizement carried out by autocratically inclined elected leaders in numerous other countries in recent years. At the same time, some of Trump’s key tactics—such as dominating and weakening the executive branch, delegitimizing and circumventing horizontal institutions, and leveraging funding and procedural restrictions against sites of societal pushback—are less common in other cases, where executives assume automatic acquiescence from executive agencies and bureaucracy, handily disempower the legislature and judiciary through constitutional changes, or push through laws that criminalize dissent and restrict civil society’s freedoms. Facing the strong institutional constraints and norms that underpin U.S. democracy, Trump’s team cannot simply follow the exact same backsliding playbook that has served executives in weaker or less consolidated democracies around the world. Instead, it must target checks and balances that are unique to the American system, using the narrower set of tools that are available to a U.S. president.",{"children":4433,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4434],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4435,"type":756,"version":757},"Nevertheless, the aggressiveness of Trump’s executive aggrandizement is worrisome. Despite the relative strength of U.S. democratic constraints, Trump has pursued his agenda with a speed that outpaces even some of the most rapid cases of democratic erosion, like Hungary and Poland. And compared to the backsliding approaches taken in countries ranging from Ecuador to India, the Trump team’s approach has been more immediate and expansive than is common. It may seem comforting that despite this rapidity, U.S. democratic backsliding is still less institutionalized or overtly repressive than many other backsliding cases. But in light of the high barriers to democratic erosion in the United States, what makes the current context especially troubling is not the relative extremity of Trump’s executive aggrandizement, but how fast and systematically he has achieved these aims within a democratic system once thought to be impervious.",{"children":4437,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4438],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4439,"type":756,"version":757},"It remains to be seen how far Trump intends to go in his aggrandizement agenda. But assessing the U.S. case in comparative analysis helps make sense of the constraints facing the administration and the pathways available to it moving forward. These conclusions start to provide lines of analysis for those who are focused on how to respond. Pushback against the administration’s strenuous, multipronged effort at executive aggrandizement, for example, will only be systematically effective if it is at least somewhat coordinated across multiple sectors and meets the Trump administration’s simultaneous assault across different political levels with a parallel set of multilevel efforts at constraint.",{"children":4441,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4442],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4443,"type":756,"version":757},"Additionally, while Trump has sought to project immense power by shattering so many democratic norms so quickly, the focal areas of his drive reveal that his administration still faces numerous constraints within U.S. democracy that pro-democracy actors can and should leverage, including 1) an executive branch that still has internal accountability mechanisms and constraints on unfettered presidential power, 2) a legal system that makes constitutional change very difficult, 3) a legislature with many veto points, and 4) a well-resourced private sector, a historically independent media sector, and a comparatively well-resourced nonprofit sector.",{"children":4445,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4446],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4447,"type":756,"version":757},"Finally, the comparative perspective highlights that U.S. democratic backsliding is not yet deeply rooted or severe, leaving significant space for pro-democracy actors to engage. But these responses must come soon, be sustained, and be ready to weather worse times ahead. As the Trump administration continues to amass power around a president driven by a reflexive intolerance toward criticism and opposition and a willingness to try to overturn any norm, process, or institution in his path, the deep roots of American democracy will be put to a full test in the months and years ahead.",{"children":4449,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":1642,"version":757,"tag":1643},[4450],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4451,"type":756,"version":757},"Acknowledgments",{"children":4453,"direction":758,"format":754,"indent":752,"type":759,"version":757},[4454],{"detail":752,"format":752,"mode":753,"style":754,"text":4455,"type":756,"version":757},"The Carnegie Endowment’s Democracy, Conflict, and Governance Program is grateful to the Hewlett Foundation for financial support that helped make the research for and writing of this paper possible. The authors thank Rachel Kleinfeld, Jennifer McCoy, and Andrew O’Donohue for comments and suggestions on a draft.
